Tableau Software xvii
Tableau Prep Help
New Features in Tableau Prep
Use the viz below to explore new features in Tableau Prep. Click on a feature to bring up the
tooltip with a link to detailed documentation for that feature. Explore the filters to refine your
search. Download the data to create a customized list.
l Use the Search by Feature dashboard to see a list of new features for a product or ver-
sion, or explore when a feature was released. The dashboard currently defaults to Tableau
Prep as the product (which includes Prep Builder and Prep Conductor features) for the ver-
sion Tableau Prep Builder.
l Use the Upgrade Prep dashboard to see a list of features specific to your upgrade. If you
publish flows to Tableau Server to run them on a schedule, some new features require a
minimum Tableau Server version to run. The view lists the minimum Tableau Server ver-
sion that supports scheduling the flows created in a specific version of Tableau Prep
Builder to help you quickly spot features with compatibility requirements.

2 Tableau Software
Tableau Prep Help
Get Started with Tableau Prep
Builder
Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, as a Creator, you can also create and edit flows on the
web. This tutorial was designed using Tableau Prep Builder, but can also be done on the
web with some noted exceptions.
This tutorial introduces you to the common operations that are available in Tableau Prep. Using
the sample data sets that come with Tableau Prep, you will walk through creating a flow for
Sample Superstore. This tutorial uses the most current version of Tableau Prep Builder. If you
are using a previous version, your results may differ.
Watch for tips along the way to gain insights into how Tableau Prep helps you clean and shape
your data for analysis.
To install Tableau Prep Builder before continuing with this tutorial, see Install Tableau Desktop or
Tableau Prep Builder from the User Interface in the Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep Builder
Deployment guide. Otherwise you can download the free trial.
Sample files
To complete the tasks in this tutorial, you need to install Tableau Prep Builder, or if web authoring
is enabled on your server version 2020.4 or later, you can also try the steps on the web.
After installing Tableau Prep Builder on your machine, you can also find the sample files in the

section: following location :
text: Here's the story...

section: following location :
text: You work at the headquarters for a large retail chain. Your boss wants to analyze product sales

section: following location :
text: and profits over the last four years for the company. You suggest that he use Tableau Desktop

section: following location :
text: to do that. Your boss thinks that's a great idea and wants you to get right on that.

section: following location :
text: As you start gathering all the data you'll need, you notice that the data has been collected and

section: following location :
text: tracked differently for each region. You also notice a lot of creative data entry in the different

section: following location :
text: files, and that one region even has a separate file for each year!

section: following location :
text: Before you can start analyzing the data in Tableau, you'll have to do some serious data cleaning

section: following location :
text: first, and it's going to be a long night.

section: following location :
text: As you rummage for restaurant menus to order some dinner, you remember that Tableau has a

section: following location :
text: product called Tableau Prep that might help you with your Herculean data cleaning tasks.

section: following location :
text: You download the product, or sign up for a free trial and decide to give it a try.

section: following location :
text: 1. Connect to data

section: following location :
text: The first thing you see when you open Tableau Prep Builder is a Start page with a Connections

section: following location :
text: pane, just like Tableau Desktop.

section: following location :
text: 4 Tableau Software

section: following location :
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following location :
text: To get started, the first step is to connect to your data and create an Input step. From there you

section: following location :
text: will start building a workflow or "flow", as it's called in Tableau Prep, and add more steps to take

section: following location :
text: action on your data as you go.

section: following location :
text: Tip: The Input step is the ingestion point for your data and the starting point for your flow. You can

section: following location :
text: have multiple Input steps and some might include multiple data files. For more information about

section: following location :
text: connecting to data, see Connect to Data on page 75.

section: following location :
text: Your sales data files for the different regions are stored in different formats, and your orders from

section: following location :
text: the South are actually multiple files. You check out the Connections pane and see that you have

section: following location :
text: a lot of choices to connect to data. Great!

section: following location :
text: Since your other regions have one file for all four years worth of data, you decide to tackle the

section: following location :
text: files from the South first.

section: following location :
text: 1. On the Connections pane, click the Add connection button.

section: following location :
text: In web authoring, from the Home page, click Create > Flow or from the Explore page,

section: following location :
text: click New > Flow. Then click Connect to Data.

section: following location :
text: 2. The files are .csv files, so select Text file in the list of connections.

section: following location :
text: 3. Navigate to the directory for your files. In the Orders South subdirectory, select the first file

section: following location :
text: orders_south_2015.csv and click Open to add it to your flow. (For file location, see Wrap

section: following location :
text: Tableau Software 5

section: following location :
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following location :
text: up and resources on page 47.)

section: following location :
text: After you connect to your first file, the Tableau Prep Builder workspace opens and you

section: following location :
text: see it is divided into two main sections. The Flow pane at the top and the Input pane at

section: following location :
text: the bottom.

section: following location :
text: Much like Tableau Desktop, this Flow pane is your workspace, where you can interact

section: following location :
text: with your data visually and build your flow. The Input pane contains configuration options

section: following location :
text: about how the data is ingested. It also shows you the fields, data types, and examples of

section: following location :
text: your values from your data set.

section: following location :
text: We'll look at how you can interact with this data in the next section.

section: following location :
text: Tip: For single tables, Tableau Prep automatically creates an Input step for you in the

section: following location :
text: Flow pane when you add data to your flow. Otherwise you can use drag-and-drop to add

section: following location :
text: tables to the Flow pane.

section: following location :
text: 4. You have three other files for your orders in the South, and how you combine them

section: following location :
text: depends on where you're working.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: a. You could add each file individually, but you want to combine all the files together

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: into one Input step, so you click the Tables tab in the Input pane.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: b. You see an option for Union multiple tables. Select it.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: You notice that the directory where you selected your file is already populated and

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: the other files you need are listed in the Included files section in the Input pane.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Tip: Using a wildcard union is a great way to connect to and combine multiple files

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: from a single data source with a similar name and structure. To use this option, the

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: files must be in the same parent or child directory. If you don't see the files you

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: 6 Tableau Software

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: need right away, change your search criteria. For more information, see Union files

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: and database tables in the Input step on page 130.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: c. Click Apply to add the data from these files to the orders_south_2015 input step.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: d. The files for the other regions are all single table files, so you can select all of the

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: files at once and add them to your flow.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Note: On the web, files can only be uploaded individually.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: The wildcard option isn't currently available for Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud. Still, you

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: want to include all of the files from the South and handle the data alike, so combining them

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: makes sense.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: a. Repeat steps 2 and 3 to add the rest of the files from the Orders South subdirectory. b. Combine them with a union step. (For more details, see Union files and database

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: tables in the Input step on page 130.)

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: i. Drag Orders_South_2016 on top of Orders_South_2015 and drop it on the

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Union option.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: ii. Drag Orders_South_2017 on top of the new Union step and drop it on Add.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tableau Software 7

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Repeat this step with the final file.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: 5. Add the remaining files.

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: l Open File Explorer or Finder and navigate to the directory for the files. Ctrl-click or

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Cmd-click (MacOS) to select the following files and drag-and-drop them onto the

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Flow pane to add them to your flow. (For file location, see Wrap up and

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: resources on page 47.)

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: l Orders_Central.csv

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: l Orders_East.xlsx

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: l Orders_West.csv

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: Note: These are different file types. If you don't see all of these files, make sure

section: In Tableau Prep Builder:
text: your file explorer or finder is set to view all file types.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: l Follow steps 2 and 3 to add Orders_Central.csv and Orders_West.csv.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: l On the Connections pane, click the Add connection button. Click Microsoft

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Excel and select Orders_East.xlsx.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: 8 Tableau Software

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Check your work: Watch "Connect to data" in action.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Click the image to replay it

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: 2. Explore your data

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Now that you have the data files loaded into Tableau Prep, you're pretty sure that you want to

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: combine all of the files together. But before you do that, it might be a good idea to take a look at

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: them first and see if you can spot any issues.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: When you select an Input step in the Flow pane, you can see the settings used to bring in the

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: data, the fields that are included, and a preview of your values.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: This is a good place to decide how much data you want to include in your flow and remove or filter

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: fields that you don't want. You can also change any data types that were assigned incorrectly.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tip: If you are working with large data sets, Tableau Prep automatically brings in a sample of the

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: data to maximize performance. If you don't see the data you expect, you might need to adjust the

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: sample. You can do this on the Data Sample tab. For more information about configuring your

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: data options and sample size, see Set your data sample size on page 121.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: In the Flow pane, as you select each step and look over each data set, you notice a few things

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: that you want to fix later and one thing that you can fix now in the Input step.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tableau Software 9

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: l Select the Orders_West Input step.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: l The State field uses abbreviations for the state name. Other files spell this out, so

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: you'll need to fix that later.

section: In Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud:
text: l There are a lot of fields that start with Right_. These fields appear to be duplicates

section: notice the following issues:
text: 3. Clean your data

section: notice the following issues:
text: In Tableau Prep, examining and cleaning your data is an iterative process. After you decide on

section: notice the following issues:
text: the data set that you want to work with, the next step is to examine and take action on that data by

section: notice the following issues:
text: applying various cleaning, shaping, and combining operations to it. You apply these operations

section: notice the following issues:
text: by adding steps to your flow. For more information about cleaning options, see Clean and Shape

section: notice the following issues:
text: Data on page 227

section: notice the following issues:
text: Steps come in many flavors, depending on what you are trying to do. For example, add a

section: notice the following issues:
text: cleaning step any time you want to apply cleaning operations to your fields like filter, merge, split,

section: notice the following issues:
text: rename, and so on. Add an aggregation step to group and aggregate fields and change the level

section: notice the following issues:
text: of detail of your data. For more information about the different step types and their uses, see

section: notice the following issues:
text: Build and Organize your Flow on page 144.

section: notice the following issues:
text: Tip: As you add steps to your flow, a flow line is automatically added to connect the steps to one

section: notice the following issues:
text: another. You can move these flow lines around and remove or add them as needed.

section: notice the following issues:
text: When you run your flow, these connection points are required so Tableau Prep knows which

section: notice the following issues:
text: steps are connected and in which order the steps apply in the flow. If a flow line is missing, the

section: notice the following issues:
text: flow will be broken and you'll get an error.

section: Builder:
text: About Tableau Prep

section: Builder:
text: Tableau Prep Builder is a tool in the Tableau product suite designed to make preparing your data

section: Builder:
text: easy and intuitive. Use Tableau Prep Builder to combine, shape, and clean your data for analysis

section: Builder:
text: Tableau Software 47

section: Builder:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Builder:
text: in Tableau.

section: Builder:
text: Note: Tableau Prep version 2019.1.2 had changed its name to Tableau Prep Builder and

section: Builder:
text: refers to the Desktop application. Starting in version 2020.4, as a Creator, you can also

section: Builder:
text: create and edit flows on Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud.

section: Builder:
text: Using Tableau Prep

section: Builder:
text: Start by connecting to your data from a variety of files, servers, or Tableau extracts. Connect to

section: Builder:
text: and combine data from multiple data sources. Drag and drop or double-click to bring your tables

section: Builder:
text: into the flow pane, and then add flow steps where you can then use familiar operations such as

section: Builder:
text: filter, split, rename, pivot, join, union and more to clean and shape your data.

section: Builder:
text: Each step in the process is represented visually in a flow chart that you create and control.

section: Builder:
text: Tableau Prep tracks each operation so that you can check your work and make changes at any

section: Builder:
text: point in the flow.

section: Builder:
text: When you are finished with your flow, run it to apply the operations to the entire data set.

section: Builder:
text: Tableau Prep works seamlessly with other Tableau products. At any point in your flow, you can

section: Builder:
text: create an extract of your data, publish your data source to Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud,

section: Builder:
text: publish your flow to Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud to continue editing on the web or refresh

section: Builder:
text: your data using a schedule. You can also open Tableau Desktop directly from within Tableau

section: Builder:
text: Prep Builder to preview your data.

section: Builder:
text: For information about installing Tableau Prep Builder, see Install Tableau Desktop or Tableau

section: Builder:
text: Prep Builder in the Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep Deployment Guide.

section: data sources, and three coordinated areas that help you interact with and explore your data:

text: Starting in version 2020.4 ,Tableau Prep supports web authoring for flows. Now you can create

section: operations (which can capture entered data values):

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: l You must be assigned a role of Explorer or higher in the server site where you are signed

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: l In Tableau Prep Builder, data source access is authorized based on the identity of the

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: user signed into the server. You will see only the data to which you have access.

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: l In Prep web authoring (Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud), data source access is also

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: authorized based on the identity of the user signed into the server. You will see only the

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: About credentials and permissions:
text: authorized based on the identity of the flow owner. The last user to publish a flow

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: About credentials and permissions:

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: You can connect to published data sources and more that are stored on Tableau Server or

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: Tableau Cloud directly from the Connect pane. If you have the Data Management with Tableau

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: Catalog enabled you can also search for and connect to databases and tables and view or filter

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: by meta data about the data sources, such as descriptions, data quality warnings, and

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: certifications.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: For more information about Tableau Catalog, see "About Tableau Catalog" in the Tableau Server

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: or Tableau Cloud Help.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: 1. Open Tableau Prep Builder and click the Add connection button.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: In web authoring, from the Home page, click Create > Flow or from the Explore page,

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: click New > Flow. Then click Connect to Data.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: 2. On the Connect pane, under Search for Data, select Tableau Server.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: 3. Sign in to connect to your server or site.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: In web authoring, the Search for data dialog opens for the sever you are signed into.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: 4. In the Search for Data dialog, search from a list of available published data sources. Use

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: the filter option to filter by connection type and certified data sources.

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

section: Tableau Prep version:

text: Connect to Virtual Connections

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2021.4.1 and later and in Tableau Server and

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: Tableau Cloud version 2021.4 and later. Data Management is required to use this feature.

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: You can connect to data using virtual connections for your flows. Virtual connections are a

section: Tableau Prep version:
text: sharable resource that provides a central access point to data.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: l Database credentials are embedded in the virtual connection. You only need to sign into

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: your server to access the tables in the virtual connection.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: l Data policies that apply row-level security can be included in the virtual connection. Only

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: tables, fields, and values you have access to are shown when working with and running

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: your flows.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: l Row-level security in virtual connections does not apply to flow output. All users with

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: access to the flow output see the same data.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: l Custom SQL and Initial SQL are not supported.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: l Parameters are not supported. For more information about using parameters in your flow,

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: see Create and Use Parameters in Flows on page 205.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: For more information about virtual connections and data policies, see the Tableau Server or

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: Tableau Cloud help.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: Connect to Tableau data extracts

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: You can connect to a data extract as input to your data flow. Extracts are saved subsets of data

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: that you can create by using filters and configuring other limits. Extracts are saved as .hyper files.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: For more information on using extracts with Tableau Prep Builder, see Save and Share Your

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: Work on page 383.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: Use Custom SQL to connect to data

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: If you know exactly the information you need from a database and understand how to write SQL

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: queries, you can use custom SQL queries to connect to data just like you can in Tableau

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: Desktop. You can use custom SQL to union your data across tables, recast fields to perform

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: cross-database joins, restructure or reduce the size of your data for analysis, and so on.

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:
text: 1. Connect to your data source, and in the Connections pane, in the Database field, select a

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: Considerations when connecting to virtual connections:

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: To determine how much of your data set to work with in the flow, you can configure your data

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: The Input step is where you can decide what and how much data to include in your flow. This is

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: always the first step in the flow.

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: If you're connected to an Excel or text file, you can also refresh the data from the Input step. For

section: To refresh your data and run the Initial SQL command do one of the following:
text: more information, see Add More Data in the Input Step on page 126.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: l Right-click or Cmd-click (MacOS) on the Input step in the flow pane to rename or remove it.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: l Union multiple files in the same parent or child directory. For more information, see Union

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: ginal sort order of your data set. See Include row numbers from your data set below.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: l Configure the field properties by changing the field name or configure the text settings for

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: text files.

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2023.1 and later and on the web for Microsoft Excel

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: and text (.csv) files.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Tableau Software 105

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Starting in version 2023.1, Tableau Prep automatically generates row numbers based on the

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: original sort order of your data that you can include as a new field in your flow. This is available

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: for Microsoft Excel or Text (.csv) file types only.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: In previous releases, if you wanted to include these row numbers, you had to manually add them

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: to the source before adding the data set to your flow.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: This field is generated in the Input step when you connect to your data. By default, it’s excluded

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: from the flow, but you can include it in one click. If you choose to include it, it behaves like any

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: other field and can be used in your flow operations and calculated fields.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Tableau Prep also supports the ROW_NUMBER function for calculated fields. This function is

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: useful when there are fields in your data set that can define the sort, such as Row ID or

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Timestamp. For more information about using this function, see Create Level of Detail, Rank,

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: and Tile Calculations on page 273.

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: Add the Source Row Number field to your flow

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: 1. Right-click or Cmd-click (MacOS) on the field, or click the More options menu and

section: In the Input step, you can:
text: select Include Field.

section: Field List:
text: 106 Tableau Software

section: Field List:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Field List:
text: The change list is cleared, the field is now part of the flow data, and you can see the

section: Field List:
text: generated row numbers in subsequent flow steps.

section: Field List:
text: Source Row Number details

section: Field List:
text: When you include the Source Row Number in your data set, the following options and

section: Field List:
text: considerations apply.

section: Field List:
text: l The data source row numbers are applied before any data sampling or filters.

section: Field List:
text: l This creates a new field called Source Row Number that persists throughout the flow.

section: Field List:
text: This field name isn't localized, but can be renamed at any time.

section: Field List:
text: l If a field with this name already exists, the new field name is incremented by 1. For

section: Field List:
text: example Source Row Number-1, Source Row Number-2, and so on.

section: Field List:
text: l You can change the field's data type in subsequent steps.

section: Field List:
text: l You can use this field in flow operations and calculations.

section: Field List:
text: l This value is regenerated for the whole data set each time the input data is refreshed or the

section: Field List:
text: flow is run.

section: Field List:
text: l This field isn’t available for input unions.

section: Field List:
text: Set header and data start row

section: Field List:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2023.3 and later and on the web for text (.csv) files

section: Field List:
text: and in version 2024.1 and later for Excel (.xls) files.

section: Field List:
text: You can set a specific row as a field header row and the row on which the data starts for Excel

section: Field List:
text: and text (.csv) files.

section: Field List:
text: When connecting to Excel or text files, a common scenario is that the files are formatted with

section: Field List:
text: meta-information in the first few rows to make them human readable. By default, Tableau Prep

section: Field List:
text: Tableau Software 107

section: Field List:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Field List:
text: interprets the first rows of CSV files as the field header row. Excel files are interpreted based on

section: Field List:
text: field types and empty rows. Tableau Prep may select a row as the header or not include a

section: Field List:
text: header row.

section: Field List:
text: For example, from the following files, STORE DETAILS is interpreted the header row.

section: Field List:

section: union:
text: By default, Tableau Prep Builder unions all .csv files in the same directory as the .csv file you

section: union:

section: union:

section: union:

text: Use the Group option to compartmentalize sections of large complex flows into folders to make it

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: easier to follow, troubleshoot, or share your flow with others. You can change the color of the

section: and dropping it on Join:

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: Requirements to group steps

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: l Steps must be directly connected with a flow line.

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: l Steps can only be included in one group at a time.

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: Tableau Software 151

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: l Groups can't be nested.

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: l You can add or remove steps from a group at any time, as long as you maintain the flow

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: line connections between steps in the group. This also applies to removing steps from a

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: flow that are already included in a group. In that scenario, the group is automatically

section: and dropping it on Join:
text: ungrouped.

section: and dropping it on Join:

section: and dropping it on Join:

text: As you build a flow, Tableau Prep Builder uses a default layout. Each flow is laid out and

section: 2. Do one of the following:

section: 2. Do one of the following:

section: 2. Do one of the following:

text: You can clean up the layout of your flow by selecting and moving steps so the flow layout is

section: 2. Do one of the following:

section: 2. Do one of the following:
text: your flow steps to clean up extra white space, or rearrange your flow steps to show a clear

section: 2. Do one of the following:

section: options to navigate:
text: 162 Tableau Software

section: options to navigate:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: options to navigate:
text: Examine Your Data

section: options to navigate:
text: Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, you can now create and edit flows in Tableau Server

section: options to navigate:
text: and Tableau Cloud. The content in this topic applies to all platforms, unless specifically

section: options to navigate:
text: noted. For more information about authoring flows on the web, see Tableau Prep on the

section: options to navigate:
text: Web in the Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud help.

section: options to navigate:
text: Use the options in this topic to get a good understanding about the composition of your data to

section: options to navigate:
text: better understand changes you need to make and the effect of the operations you include in the

section: options to navigate:
text: flow.

section: options to navigate:
text: Review the data types assigned to your data

section: options to navigate:
text: Like Tableau Desktop, Tableau Prep interprets the data in your fields when you drag a

section: options to navigate:
text: connection to the Flow pane and automatically assigns a data type to it. Because different

section: options to navigate:
text: databases can handle data in different ways, Tableau Prep's interpretation might not always be

section: options to navigate:
text: correct.

section: options to navigate:
text: To change a data type, click the data type icon and select the correct data type from the context

section: options to navigate:
text: menu. You can change string or integer data types to Date or Date & Time, and Tableau Prep

section: options to navigate:
text: will trigger Auto DateParse to change these data types. Like Tableau Desktop, if the change is

section: options to navigate:
text: not successful you will see Null values in the fields instead and you can create a calculation to

section: options to navigate:
text: make the change.

section: options to navigate:
text: For more information about using DateParse, see Convert a Field to a Date Field in the Tableau

section: options to navigate:
text: Desktop and Web Authoring Help.

section: options to navigate:
text: Tableau Software 163

section: options to navigate:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: options to navigate:
text: You can change the data type in your Input step after connecting to data from the following data

section: sources:
text: l Microsoft Excel

section: sources:
text: l Text files

section: sources:
text: l PDF files

section: sources:
text: l Box

section: sources:
text: l Dropbox

section: sources:
text: l Google Drive

section: sources:
text: l OneDrive

section: sources:
text: For all other data sources, add a cleaning step or other step type to make this change. To see a

section: sources:
text: list of cleaning options available in the different step types, see About cleaning operations on

section: sources:
text: page 227.

section: sources:
text: See size details about your data

section: sources:
text: After you connect to your data, add a table to the flow, and then add a step. You can use the

section: sources:
text: Profile pane to see the current state and structure of your data and spot nulls and outliers.

section: sources:
text: l Number of fields and rows: In the upper-left corner of the Profile pane you can find

section: sources:
text: information that summarizes the number of fields and rows in the data at a particular point

section: sources:
text: in the flow. Tableau Prep rounds to the nearest thousand. In the example below, there are

section: sources:
text: 164 Tableau Software

section: sources:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: sources:
text: 21 fields and 3000 rows in the data set.

section: sources:
text: When you hover over the number of fields and rows, you can see the exact number of rows

section: sources:
text: (in this example, 2848).

section: sources:
text: l Data set size: Work with a subset of your data by specifying the number of rows to include

section: sources:
text: in the Data Sample tab in the Inputpane.

section: sources:
text: l Sampled: To enable you to interact directly with your data, Tableau Prep works with a

section: sources:
text: subset of your raw data. The number of rows is determined by the data types and number

section: sources:
text: of fields that are being rendered. String fields take more storage space than integers, so if

section: sources:
text: you have 10 fields of strings in your data set, you might get fewer rows than if you had 10

section: sources:
text: fields of integers.

section: sources:
text: Tableau Software 165

section: sources:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: sources:
text: A Sampled badge displays next to the size details in the Profile pane to indicate

section: sources:
text: that this is a subset of your data set. You can modify the amount of data that you include

section: sources:
text: in your flow. When creating or editing flows on the web, additional data limits apply. For

section: sources:
text: more information, see Set your data sample size on page 121.

section: sources:
text: l Number of unique values: The number next to each field header represents the distinct

section: sources:
text: values that are contained within that field. Tableau Prep rounds to the nearest thousand.

section: sources:
text: In the example below, there are 3,000 distinct values that are represented in the

section: sources:
text: Description field, but if you hover over the number, you can see the exact number of

section: sources:
text: unique values.

section: sources:
text: See the distribution of values or unique values

section: sources:
text: By default, Tableau Prep groups numerical, date, and date & time values in a field into buckets.

section: sources:
text: These buckets are also known as bins. The bins ensure that you can see the distribution of

section: sources:
text: values as a whole and quickly identify outliers and null values.  The bin size is calculated based

section: sources:
text: on the minimum and maximum values in the field, and null values are always shown at the top of

section: sources:
text: the distribution.

section: sources:
text: For example, order and ship dates are summarized or "binned" by year. Each bin represents a

section: sources:
text: year from January of the beginning year to January of the following year and labeled

section: sources:
text: 166 Tableau Software

section: sources:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: sources:
text: accordingly. Because there are sales dates and ship dates that fall in the latter part of 2018 and

section: sources:
text: 2019, a bin is created for the following year for those values.

section: sources:
text: If a discrete (or categorical) data field contains many rows or has a distribution that is large

section: sources:
text: enough that it can’t be displayed in the field without scrolling, you can see a summarized

section: sources:
text: distribution to the right of the field. You can click and scroll through the distribution to target

section: sources:
text: specific values.

section: sources:
text: When your data contains numeric or date fields, you can toggle to display the detailed (discrete)

section: sources:
text: version of the values or a summarized (continuous) version of the values. The summarized view

section: sources:
text: shows you the range of values in a field and the frequency with which certain values appear.

section: sources:
text: Tableau Software 167

section: sources:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: sources:
text: This toggle can help you isolate unique values (like the number of “3” records in a field) or the

section: sources:
text: distribution of values (like the sum of all “3” records in a field)

section: To toggle your view:
text: 1. In the Profile pane, Results pane or data grid, click the More options menu for a

section: To toggle your view:
text: numeric or date field.

section: To toggle your view:
text: 2. In the context menu, select Detail to see the detailed version of the values, or Summary

section: To toggle your view:
text: to see the distributed version of the values.

section: To toggle your view:
text: Search for fields and values

section: To toggle your view:
text: In the Profile pane or Results pane, you can search for fields or values of particular interest to

section: To toggle your view:
text: you and use the search results to filter your data.

section: To toggle your view:
text: Starting in version 2021.1.1, when you search for fields, a new indicator will show telling you the

section: To toggle your view:
text: number of fields found so you can better understand your search results. If no fields are found,

section: To toggle your view:
text: additional messaging will show.

section: To toggle your view:
text: To search for fields, enter a full or partial search term in the search box on the toolbar.

section: To toggle your view:
text: 168 Tableau Software

section: To toggle your view:

text: Reorder fields

section: To search for a value in a field:
text: Changing the order of fields using the list view is supported in version 2022.2.1 and later.

section: To search for a value in a field:
text: You can change the order of fields from the Profile pane, Data grid, or List view by dragging and

section: To search for a value in a field:
text: dropping them into a new position.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 1. From the Profile pane, Results pane, Data grid, or List view, select one or more profile

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: cards or fields. 2. Drag the profile card or field until you see the black target line appear. 3. Drop the profile card or field into place.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The Profile pane, data grid, and list view are synced so the field will appear in the same

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: order in all places. The new order for the fields is persistent across Tableau products

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: when running and scheduling flows.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Data Grid reorder

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Highlight fields and values in a flow

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep makes it easy to find fields and values in your flow data. Trace where a field

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: originated and where it is used throughout the flow in the flow pane, or click individual values in a

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: profile card or in the data grid to highlight related or identical values.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Trace fields in a flow

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: In Tableau Prep, you can highlight everywhere a field is used in a flow, even where it originated to

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: help you track down missing values or troubleshoot a flow when you aren't seeing the results you

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: expect.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Click on a field in the Profile pane in a cleaning step or in the Results pane in any other step type

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: and the flow pane will highlight the path where that field is used.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: This option is not available for Input or Output step types.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 173

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: See related values

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: You can use highlighting to find related values across fields. When you click a value in the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Profile card in the Profile pane or Results pane, all the related values in the other fields are

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: highlighted in blue. The blue color shows the relationship distribution between the value you

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: selected and the values in the other fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: For example, to highlight related values, in the Profile pane, click a value in a field. The related

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: values in other fields turn blue and the proportion of the bar highlighted in blue represents the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: degree of association.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Highlight identical values

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: When you select a value in the data grid, all identical values are highlighted too. These

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: highlights help you identify patterns or irregularities in your data.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 174 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Filter Your Data

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, you can now create and edit flows in Tableau Server

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: and Tableau Cloud. The content in this topic applies to all platforms, unless specifically

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: noted. For more information about authoring flows on the web, see Tableau Prep on the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Web in the Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud help.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep provides various options that you can use to filter your data. For example, use

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Keep Only or Exclude to do one-click filtering on a specific value for a field in a profile card, data

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: grid or results card, or select from a variety of filter options for more complex filtering needs. You

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: can also keep or remove entire fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Filter data at any step in the flow. If you want to simply change a specific value, you can select

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Edit Value to edit the value in-line or replace the value with Null. For more information about

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: editing field values, see Edit field values on page 247.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 175

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Keep or remove fields

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: As you work with your data in your flow you might want to remove unwanted fields. In the Profile

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: pane or the data grid in any cleaning or action step, select one or more fields and right-click or

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Ctrl-click (MacOS) and select Remove to remove the selected fields, or select Keep Only

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: (Tableau Prep Builder version 2019.2.2 and later and on the web) to keep only the selected

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: fields and remove all unselected fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 176 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Hide fields

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2021.1.4 and later and Tableau Server or Tableau

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Cloud starting in version 2021.1.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: If you have fields in your flow that don’t need cleaning, but you still want to include them in your

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: flow, you can hide the fields instead of removing them. Data for those fields won't be loaded until

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: you either unhide the fields or run your flow to generate your output.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: When you hide fields, a new profile card called Hidden Fields is automatically added to the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Profile pane, letting you easily unhide fields from the list as you need them.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: You can include hidden fields in most operations, but joins, aggregations, and pivots require the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: field to be unhidden to use it in one of these step types. If you hide the field after it has been used

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: in one of these operations, the field will show as hidden and the operation won't be affected.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: All hidden fields are tagged with an eye icon.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 177

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Hide and unhide fields

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: To hide or unhide fields, you must be in an Input step or in a Clean step. In the Clean step you

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: can hide or unhide fields from the Profile pane, date grid, and List view.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: From the Input step

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 1. Connect to your data. 2. In the Input step select the field you want to hide or unhide.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 3. Click the eye icon to hide or unhide the field.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Multi-selecting fields in the Input step is supported starting in version 2023.1.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: From the Profile pane

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 178 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 1. Select the fields you want to hide.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 2. Right-click, Ctrl-click (MacOS), from the More options menu, or from the toolbar

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: menu, select Hide Field or Hide Fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 3. A new profile card is generated showing your hidden fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 4. To unhide fields, in the Hidden Fields profile card, select one or more fields, and either

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: click the eye icon, right-click, or Ctrl-click (MacOS) and select Unhide Fields from the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: menu.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: From the List view

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 1. In a Clean step, on the toolbar, click the List view icon to change to the list view.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 2. Select one or more fields to hide or unhide.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 179

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 3. Click the eye icon to hide or unhide the fields.

text: Where are my filter options?

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: To see the different filter options available for your fields, on the profile card, in the data grid or in

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: the results pane, click the More options menu. To see the menu on the data grid, you must

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: click the Hide profile pane button first, and then click More options .

text: 180 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Calculation filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: When you select Calculation, the Add Filter dialog box opens. Enter the calculation, verify that

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: it's valid, and click Save. Starting in version 2021.4.1 you can also include parameters in

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: calculation filters. For more information, see Apply user parameters to filter calculations on

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: page 219.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: In the Input step this is the only type of filter that is available. All other filter types are

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: available in the profile cards, data grid or results pane.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 181

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Selected Values filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: In Tableau Prep Builder version 2019.2.3 and later and on the web, you can use the Selected

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Values filter to pick and choose the values that you want to keep or exclude for a field, even

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: values that aren't in your sample. In the right pane, click the Keep Only or Exclude tab to select

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: your action, then enter search terms to search for values or click Add a value to add values

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: that are in your data set but aren't included in your sample. Click Done to apply your filter.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: This filter options isn't available for Aggregation or Pivot step types.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Range of Values filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Filter out values that fall within a specific range. When you select Range of Values, you can

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: specify a range or set minimum or maximum values.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 182 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Range of Dates filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Filter out values that fall within a specific date range. When you select Range of Dates, you can

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: specify a range of dates or set a minimum or maximum date.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Relative Date filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Use the Relative Dates filter to specify the exact range of years, quarters, months, weeks, or

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: days that you want to see in your data. You can also configure an anchor relative to a specific

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: date, and include null values.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: “Last” date periods include the complete current unit of time, even if some dates

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: haven't occurred yet. For example, if you select the last month and the current date is

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: January 7th, Tableau will display dates for January 1st through January 31st.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 183

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Wildcard Match filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: When you select Wildcard Match, you can filter the field values to keep or exclude values that

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: match a pattern. In the filter editor, select the Keep Only or Exclude tab, enter a value to match

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: and then set the Matching Options criteria to return the values you are looking for.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The filtered results display in the left pane of the filter editor so that you can review and

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: experiment with your results. Once you have the results you want, click Done to apply your

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: change.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Null Values filter

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: When you select Null Values you can filter the values in the selected field to show only null

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: values or exclude all null values.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 184 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Remove Duplicate Rows

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2024.1 and later, Tableau Server version 2024.2 and

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: later, and on the web in Tableau Cloud.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Duplicate data can have an impact on your data quality, bias prediction results, and waste

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: storage space. Removing duplicates ensures that each value is unique, providing an accurate

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: representation of your data. The first step to removing duplicates is to identify the duplicate rows

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: in your data. After you've identified duplicates, you can then remove them from the work flow.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Identify and remove duplicates

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep identifies a duplicate as any row that has at least one other row with the same

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: values.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: To identify and remove duplicate rows.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 1. (Optional) For Excel and text files, you can click on the Input step and add a Source Row

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Number field to sort rows by the original data source. For more information, see Add the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Source Row Number field to your flow and Sort order for the calculated field on

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: page 189. 2. Click on any step other than an Input or Output step.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 185

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 3. Identify duplicate rows.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: l To identify duplicate rows across all fields, from the toolbar, click Identify Duplic-

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: ate Rows.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: l To identify duplicate rows across specific fields, select one or more fields, then

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: click Identify Duplicate Rows. Optionally, in the profile pane, you can click the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: More options menu from the selected field and select Identify Duplicate

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Rows.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: A calculated field is created and listed in the Changes pane. The calculated field provides

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: a description and the names of the fields that the duplicate rows span. The Data Grid

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: shows which rows are unique and which rows are duplicates.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The following image shows the results of selecting the two fields Region and Item Type to

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: identify duplicate rows across only those selected fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 186 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: If a Source Row Number is available, it’s used to sort the order of the rows. Otherwise,

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: rows are sorted based on the first field in the table schema. To change the values in the

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: calculated field, you can directly edit the calculation or write your own calculation. See Sort

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: order for the calculated field on page 189. 4. To evaluate duplicate rows, click on Duplicate or Unique in the Is Duplicate Row? field or

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: in the Data Grid.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The following image shows duplicate rows across all fields.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The following image shows duplicate rows across only the fields Region and Item Type.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Software 187

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 5. To filter and keep only the unique rows, click Unique in the Data grid or in the Is Duplicate

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Row? field, and select Keep Only from the toolbar. Optionally, you can click Unique in

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: the Data grid or in the Is Duplicate Row? field, then right-click to select Keep Only.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: You can also select Duplicate and then select Exclude to filter data for duplicates. This

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: produces the same results as selecting Unique and Keep Only and doesn’t affect which

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: rows are excluded or kept.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: A filter is created in the changes pane showing that only unique rows are kept and

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: duplicate rows are excluded.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 188 Tableau Software

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: 6. From the Is Duplicate Row? calculated field, click the More options menu, and select

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Remove.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: The duplicate rows are removed when you run the flow and create an output.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Note: Don’t remove the Is Duplicate Row? calculated field if you’ll be adjusting for

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: sampled data.

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Duplicates in sample data

section: To rearrange the order of your fields:
text: Duplicate rows may not appear in sampled data and could introduce a bias in the model.

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: 1. Don’t remove the Is Duplicate Row? calculated field if you’ll be adjusting for sampled

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: data. This gives you the option to change the sample size or adjust the sample data in the

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: input step. 2. Adjust the sample size to load as much data as possible for row selection. See Set your

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: data sample size. 3. Duplicates may not appear in sampled data depending on the size of the sample. Using

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: the Keep Only option for unique rows allows you to remove duplicate rows, even if they

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: aren’t visible in the sampled data.

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: Sort order for the calculated field

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: By default, if multiple rows contain the same value, they’re sorted by the first field, or if available,

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: the Source Row Number. The fields are used to identify the first row as Unique and the remaining

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: as Duplicate. Changing the sort order of fields allows you to specify which duplicate row you want

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: Tableau Software 189

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: to identify as Unique. You can make changes to the order by editing the calculation and

section: To address duplicate rows sampled data:
text: changing the ORDERBY field.

section: For example:
text: IF ({PARTITION [Field1], [Field2], [Field3]: { ORDERBY [FieldName]

section: For example:
text: ASC: ROW_NUMBER() } } = 1) THEN 'Unique' ELSE 'Duplicate' END

section: For example:
text: For Excel and text files, you can sort by the original data source by adding a Source Row

section: For example:
text: Number field.

section: For example:
text: IF ({PARTITION [Source Row Number], [Field1], [Field2], [Field3]: {

section: For example:
text: ORDERBY [Source Row Number] DESC: ROW_NUMBER() } } = 1) THEN 'Unique'

section: For example:
text: ELSE 'Duplicate' END

section: For example:
text: For more information, see Add the Source Row Number field to your flow.

section: For example:
text: Write your own filter calculation to find and remove duplicates

section: For example:
text: You can write your own filter calculation across multiple fields to find and remove duplicates.

section: For example:
text: The following filter calculation will only return results that return True. The calculation returns

section: For example:

section: ROW_NUMBER() } } = 1
text: Use CASE or IF for identify duplicate calculations

section: ROW_NUMBER() } } = 1 WHEN TRUE THEN 'UNIQUE' ELSE 'DUPLICATE' END

section: ROW_NUMBER() } } = 1 WHEN TRUE THEN 'UNIQUE' ELSE 'DUPLICATE' END

section: END
text: Use data roles to quickly identify whether the values in a field are valid or not. Tableau Prep

section: END
text: delivers a standard set of data roles that you can select from or you can create your own using

section: END
text: the unique field values in your data set.

section: END
text: When you assign a data role, Tableau Prep compares the standard values defined for the data

section: END
text: role with the values in your field. Any values that don't match are marked with a red exclamation

section: END
text: mark. You can filter your field to view only the valid or invalid values and take the appropriate

section: END
text: actions to fix them. Once you've assigned a data role to your fields, you can use the Group

section: END
text: Values option to group and match invalid values to valid ones based on spelling and

section: END
text: pronunciation.

section: END
text: Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, you can now create and edit flows in Tableau Server

section: END
text: and Tableau Cloud. The content in this topic applies to all platforms, unless specifically

section: END
text: noted. For more information about authoring flows on the web, see Tableau Prep on the

section: END
text: Web in the Tableau Server help.

section: END
text: Assign standard data roles to your data

section: END
text: Assign data roles provided by Tableau Prep to your field the same way you assign a data type.

section: END
text: The data role identifies what your data values represent so Tableau Prep can automatically

section: END
text: validate values and highlight ones that aren't valid for that role.

section: END
text: Tableau Software 191

section: END
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: END
text: For example if you have field values for geographical data, you can assign a data role of City

section: END
text: and Tableau Prep compares the values in the field to a set of known domain values to identify

section: END
text: values that don't match.

section: END
text: Note: Each field is analyzed independently so a City value of "Portland" in State

section: END
text: "Washington" in Country "USA" might not be a valid city and state combination, but it

section: END
text: won't be identified that way because it is a valid city name.

text: Delete user parameters

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: To delete user parameters that you no longer need, click Delete Parameter in the Edit

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Parameter dialog. This removes any instance of the parameter used throughout the flow and

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: replaces it with the parameter's Current value. This action can't be undone.

text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: 1. From the top menu, click the parameter icon drop-down menu.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: 2. For the parameter that you want to delete, click View in flow to find all instances where the

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: parameter is used in the flow.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: If the parameter is not used anywhere in the flow skip to step 4. 3. For each step where the parameter is used, remove the parameter, including deleting any

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: changes listed in the Changes pane.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: 4. From the top menu, click the parameter icon drop-down menu and for the parameter

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: you want to delete, click Edit parameter.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: 5. In the Edit Parameter dialog, click Delete Parameter.

text: The parameter will be replaced with the parameter's Current value.

text: Run flows with parameters

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Running flows that include parameters is the same as running flows that don't have them, except

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: that users are prompted to enter user parameter values at run time or when adding the flow to a

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: schedule in Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: System parameters are applied automatically when the flow is run.

text: If a user parameter is marked as a required, users must enter a value before they can run the

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: flow. If a parameter is optional, users can enter a value or accept the parameter's Current value

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: by default.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Required parameters are those that have the Require selection at run time (Prompt for

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: value at run time in prior releases) check box selected.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: If you run flows using the command line interface and want to override the current (default)

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: command line on page 427.

text: When you run a flow from Tableau Prep Builder or manually in Tableau Server or Tableau

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Cloud, the Parameters dialog opens when you click Run.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: 1. Enter or select the user parameter values. If there are optional parameters in the flow, you

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: can enter the values at this time or accept the current (default) parameter value. 2. Click Run Flow to run the flow.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: When you schedule flows to run on Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud, you will need to enter any

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
