section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Clean and Shape Data

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Tableau Prep offers various cleaning operations that you can use to clean and shape your data.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Cleaning up dirty data makes it easier to combine and analyze your data or makes it easier for

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: others to understand your data when sharing your data sets.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: You can also clean your data using a pivot step or a script step to apply R or Python scripts to

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: your flow. Script steps aren’t supported in Tableau Cloud. For more information, see Pivot Your

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Data on page 331 or Use R and Python scripts in your flow on page 340.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: About cleaning operations

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: You clean data by applying cleaning operations such as filtering, adding, renaming, splitting,

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: grouping, or removing fields. You can perform cleaning operations in most step types in your

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: flow. You can also perform cleaning operations in the data grid in a cleaning step.

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: You can apply limited cleaning operations in the Input step and can't apply cleaning operations in

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: the output step. For more information about applying cleaning operations in the Input step, see

section: In an Output step you can apply date and time system parameters to the following places:
text: Apply cleaning operations in an input step on page 114.

text: Note: For joins, if the field is a calculated field that was created using a field from one table,

section: tion:
text: Apply cleaning operations

section: tion:
text: To apply cleaning operations to fields, use the toolbar options or click More options on the

section: tion:
text: field profile card, data grid, or Results pane to open the menu.

section: tion:
text: In Aggregate, Pivot, Join, and Union step types, the More options menu is available on the

section: tion:
text: profile cards in the Results pane and corresponding data grid. If you perform the same cleaning

section: tion:
text: operations or actions over and over throughout your flow, you can copy and paste your steps,

section: tion:
text: actions, or even fields. For more information see Copy steps, actions and fields on page 260.

section: tion:
text: Profile pane toolbar Drop-down menu

section: tion:
text: Tableau Software 231

section: tion:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: tion:
text: Select your view

section: tion:
text: You can perform cleaning operations outside of the profile or results pane in the data grid or in

section: tion:
text: the list view. Use the view toolbar to change your view, then click

section: tion:
text: More options on a field to open the cleaning menu.

section: tion:
text: l

section: tion:
text: Show profile pane: This is the default view. Select this button to go back to the Pro-

section: tion:
text: file pane or Results pane view.

section: tion:
text: 232 Tableau Software

section: tion:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: tion:
text: l

section: tion:
text: Show data grid: Collapse the profile or results pane to expand and show only the

section: tion:
text: data grid. This view provides a more detailed view of your data and can be useful when

section: tion:
text: you need to work with specific field values. After you select this option, this view state per-

section: tion:
text: sists across all steps in your flow but you can change it at any time.

section: tion:
text: Note: Not all cleaning operations are available in the data grid. For example if you

section: tion:
text: want to edit a value in-line, you must use the Profile pane.

section: tion:
text: l

section: tion:
text: Show list view (Tableau Prep Builderon the web): Convert the profile pane or results

section: tion:
text: pane into a list. After you select this option, this view state persists across all steps in your

section: tion:
text: flow but you can change it at any time.

section: In this view you can:
text: l Select and remove multiple rows using the X option.

section: In this view you can:
text: l

section: In this view you can:
text: Select and hide or unhide multiple rows using the option.

section: In this view you can:
text: l Rename fields in bulk.

section: In this view you can:
text: Tableau Software 233

section: In this view you can:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In this view you can:
text: l Use the More options menu to apply operations to selected fields.

section: In this view you can:
text: If you assign a data role to the field, or select Filter, Group Values, Clean, or Split

section: In this view you can:
text: Values, you're returned to the Profile or Results view to complete those actions. All

section: In this view you can:
text: other options can be performed in the list view.

section: In this view you can:
text: Pause data updates to boost performance

section: In this view you can:
text: As you perform cleaning operations on your data, Tableau Prep applies your changes as you go

section: In this view you can:
text: to show you the results immediately. To save valuable processing time when you know the

section: In this view you can:
text: changes you need to make and don't need immediate feedback as you make each change, you

section: In this view you can:
text: can boost performance by pausing data updates.

section: In this view you can:
text: When you pause data updates, you can make all your changes at once, then resume updates to

section: In this view you can:
text: see your results. You can resume data updates and enable all available operations at any time.

section: In this view you can:
text: Note: When you pause data updates, any operations that require you to see your values

section: In this view you can:
text: are disabled. For example if you want to apply a filter to selected values, you need to see

section: In this view you can:
text: the values you want to exclude.

section: In this view you can:
text: 234 Tableau Software

section: In this view you can:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In this view you can:
text: 1. In the top menu, click Pause data updates to pause updates.

section: In this view you can:
text: 2. Tableau Prep converts the Profile pane into the List view. In List view, use the More

section: In this view you can:
text: options menu to apply operations to selected fields. If the operation requires you to see

section: In this view you can:
text: your values, it is disabled. To enable the operation, you must resume data updates.

section: In this view you can:
text: For more information about using List view mode, see Select your view on page 232.

section: In this view you can:
text: 3. To see the results of your changes or enable a disabled feature, resume data updates.

section: In this view you can:
text: Click the Resume data updates button, click the Resume button in the menu dialog or in

section: In this view you can:
text: the message banner at the top of the Flow pane.

section: In this view you can:
text: Note: Tableau Prep Builder gives you an option to resume updates directly from the

section: In this view you can:
text: menu. If editing flows on the web, you'll need to resume updates from the top menu.

section: In this view you can:
text: Tableau Software 235

section: In this view you can:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: In this view you can:
text: Apply cleaning operations

section: To apply cleaning operations to a field, do the following:
text: 1. In the Profile pane, data grid, Results pane, or list view, select the field you want to make

section: To apply cleaning operations to a field, do the following:
text: changes to.

section: To apply cleaning operations to a field, do the following:
text: 2. From either the toolbar or More options menu for the field , select from the following

section: options:
text: l Filter or Filter Values: Select from one of the filter options, right-click or Ctrl-click

section: options:
text: (MacOS) a field value to keep or exclude values. You can also use the Selected

section: options:
text: Values filter to pick and choose the values to filter, included values not in your flow

section: options:
text: sample. For more information about filter options, see Filter Your Data on

section: options:
text: page 175.

section: options:
text: l Group Values (Group and Replace in prior versions): Manually select values or

section: options:
text: use automatic grouping. You can also multi-select values in the Profile card and

section: options:
text: right-click or Ctrl-click (MacOS) to group or ungroup values or edit the group value.

section: options:
text: For more information about using Group Values, see Automatically map values

section: options:
text: to a standard value using fuzzy match on page 256.

section: options:
text: l Clean: Select from a list of quick cleaning operations to apply to all values in the

section: options:
text: field.

section: options:
text: l Convert Dates: For fields assigned to a Date or Date & Time data type, select from

section: options:
text: a list of DATEPART quick cleaning operations to convert your date field values to

section: options:
text: an integer value representing year, quarter, month, week, day, or a date and time

section: options:
text: value. You can also select from two DATENAME quick cleaning operations, day of

section: options:
text: the week or month name, to convert your date field values.

section: options:
text: 236 Tableau Software

section: options:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: options:
text: l Custom Fiscal Year : If your fiscal year doesn't start in January, you can set

section: options:
text: a custom fiscal month to convert the date using that month instead of the

section: options:
text: default month of January.

section: options:
text: l This setting is on a per field basis, so if you want to apply a custom fiscal year

section: options:
text: to other fields, repeat this same step.

section: options:
text: l To open the dialog, from the More options menu, select Convert Dates >

section: options:
text: Custom Fiscal Year.

section: options:
text: l Split Values: Split values automatically based on a common separator or use cus-

section: options:
text: tom split to specify how you want to split field values. Automatic split and custom

section: options:
text: split work the same as they do in Tableau Desktop. For more information, see Split a

section: options:
text: Field into Multiple Fields in the Tableau Desktop and Web Authoring Help.

section: options:
text: l Rename Field: Edit the field name.

section: options:
text: l Duplicate Field: Create a copy of your field and values.

section: options:
text: l Keep Only Field: Keep only the selected field and exclude all other fields in the

section: options:
text: step.

section: options:
text: l Create Calculated Field: Write a custom calculation in the Calculation editor or use

section: options:
text: the Visual Calculation editor to create level of detail, rank or row number cal-

section: options:
text: culations. For more information, see Create Level of Detail, Rank, and Tile Cal-

section: options:
text: culations on page 273.

section: options:
text: l Publish as Data Role: Create custom data roles that you can then apply to your

section: options:
text: fields to validate the field values when cleaning data. For more information about

section: options:
text: this option, see Create custom data roles on page 194.

section: options:
text: Tableau Software 237

section: options:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: options:
text: l Hide Field: If you have fields you want to keep in your flow but don't need to clean,

section: options:
text: you can hide them out of the way instead of removing them. For more information,

section: options:
text: see Hide fields on page 177.

section: options:
text: l Remove: Remove the field from the flow. 3. To edit a value, right-click or Ctrl-click (MacOS) one or more values and select Edit Value

section: options:
text: then enter a new value. You can also select Replace with Null to replace the values with

section: options:
text: a Null value or double-click in a single field to edit it directly. For more information about

section: options:
text: editing field values see Edit field values on page 247. 4. Review the results of these operations in the Profile pane, Summary panes or data grid.

section: options:
text: Rename fields in bulk

section: options:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Builder version 2021.2.1 and later. Supported in Tableau Prep on

section: options:
text: the web in Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud version 2021.2 and later.

section: options:
text: Use the Rename Fields option to rename multiple fields in bulk. Search for parts of a field name

section: options:
text: to replace or remove it, or add prefixes or suffixes to all or selected fields in your data set.

section: options:
text: You can also automatically apply the same change to any fields added in the future that match

section: options:
text: your criteria by selecting the Automatically rename new fields check box when making your

section: options:
text: changes.

section: options:
text: Note: This option is only available in a Clean step type.

section: options:
text: 1. In a Clean step, from the toolbar, select Rename Fields.

text: This option uses the ngram fingerprint algorithm that indexes words by their unique char-

section: Choose one of the following options to group values:
text: acters after removing punctuation, duplicates, and whitespace. This algorithm works for

section: Choose one of the following options to group values:

section: Choose one of the following options to group values:

section: Choose one of the following options to group values:

section: Choose one of the following options to group values:

section: 2. In the flow pane, do one of the following:
text: When you have gaps in your sequential data set, you may need to fill those gaps with new rows

section: 2. In the flow pane, do one of the following:
text: to effectively analyze your data or perform trend analysis. You can use the New Rows step type

section: 2. In the flow pane, do one of the following:
text: to generate the missing rows and set configuration options to get the results you need.

section: 2. In the flow pane, do one of the following:
text: New rows can be generated for fields with numeric (whole numbers) or date values.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Generate rows using values from a single field or two fields

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Use all data in the field or select a range of values

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Create a new field with the results or add the new rows to your existing fields

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Set the increment (up to 10,000) to use when generating the new rows

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Set the values for the new rows to be zero, Null, or copy the value from the previous row.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Examples

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Example 1: You have a table of sales data, but there are some days where no sales are

section: Configuration options include:
text: recorded. You need a row for every day, not just the days where you had sales. With New

section: Configuration options include:
text: Rows you can generate rows for your missing days and add them to you existing field

section: Configuration options include:
text: "Days of the week". Since no sales are recorded for those days, you want the quantity

section: Configuration options include:
text: sold value to be zero.

section: Configuration options include:
text: 270 Tableau Software

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Example 2: You have a table of sales data where orders filled is recorded using a range of

section: Configuration options include:
text: dates. You need a row for each day. Since you don't know how many orders were filled

section: Configuration options include:
text: each day, you want the values for the new rows to be Null. With New Rows you can

section: Configuration options include:
text: generate the missing rows between the two dates, and create a new field called "All Days"

section: Configuration options include:
text: to preserve your original data.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Generate new rows

section: Configuration options include:
text: 1. In the Flow pane, click the plus icon, and select New Rows. A New Rows step

section: Configuration options include:
text: displays in the Flow pane.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Complete the following steps to configure your options to generate the new rows. 2. How do you want to add new rows? Use one of the following options to select the field

section: Configuration options include:
text: or fields where rows are missing.

section: Configuration options include:
text: a. Values from one field: Generate missing rows from values in a single field. Use

section: Configuration options include:
text: this option for Number (whole) or Date data types.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Software 271

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Configuration options include:
text: By default, use the minimum and maximum value to generate missing rows. This

section: Configuration options include:
text: option uses all values in the field. If you only want to use a range of values to

section: Configuration options include:
text: generate the missing rows, set a Start value and End value.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Note: The Start value and End value fields can't be used to generate rows

section: Configuration options include:
text: outside of your current data set.

section: Configuration options include:
text: b. Value ranges from two fields: Generate new rows using a value range between

section: Configuration options include:
text: two date fields. This option is only available for Date data types, uses all values in

section: Configuration options include:
text: the field, and requires that both fields have the same data type. 3. Where do you want to add the new rows? When using a single field you can add the

section: Configuration options include:
text: new rows to your existing field or create a new field to preserve your original data. When

section: Configuration options include:
text: using value ranges from two fields, you must create a new field.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Field Name: Enter a name for the new field.

section: Configuration options include:
text: 4. Specify your increment value: Enter a value from 1-10,000. Each new row is incre-

section: Configuration options include:
text: mented by the value you select. If you select a value that is greater than the gap between

section: Configuration options include:
text: values, no new rows are generated.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Number fields: Select a numeric value.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Date fields: Select a numeric value and select Day, Week, or Month.

section: Configuration options include:
text: 5. What values should your new rows have?: Select an option to fill in the other field

section: Configuration options include:
text: values for the new rows.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Null: Populate all field values with Null.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Null or zero: Populate all text values with Null and all numeric values with zero.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Copy from previous row: Populate all field values with the value from the pre-

section: Configuration options include:
text: vious row.

section: Configuration options include:
text: 272 Tableau Software

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Configuration options include:
text: New rows are shown in the Generated Rows pane in bold as you enter your configuration

section: Configuration options include:
text: settings. The row details are shown in the New Rows Results pane.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Create Level of Detail, Rank, and Tile Cal-

section: Configuration options include:
text: culations

section: Configuration options include:
text: Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, you can now create and edit flows in Tableau Server

text: and Tableau Cloud. The content in this topic applies to all platforms, unless specifically

section: Configuration options include:
text: You can use calculated fields to create new data using data that already exists in your data

section: Configuration options include:
text: source. Tableau Prep supports many of the same calculation types as Tableau Desktop. For

section: Configuration options include:
text: general information about creating calculations, see Get Started with Calculations in Tableau.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Note: When creating a calculated field, don't use the reserved name "Number of Records".

section: Configuration options include:
text: Using this reserved name will result in a permission-related error.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Starting in version 2020.1.3 Tableau Prep Builder and on the web, you can use FIXED Level of

section: Configuration options include:
text: Detail (LOD) and RANK and ROW_NUMBER analytic functions to perform more complex

section: Configuration options include:
text: calculations.

section: Configuration options include:
text: For example, add a FIXED LOD calculation to change the granularity of fields in your table, use

section: Configuration options include:
text: the ROW_NUMBER () analytic function to quickly find duplicate rows, or use one of the RANK ()

section: Configuration options include:
text: functions to find the top N or bottom N values for a selection of rows with similar data. If you want

section: Configuration options include:
text: a more guided experience when building these types of expressions, you can use the visual

section: Configuration options include:
text: calculation editor.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Software 273

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Configuration options include:
text: Starting in version 2021.4.1 Tableau Prep Builder and on the web, you can use the tile feature to

section: Configuration options include:
text: distribute rows into a specified number of buckets.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Note: Some functions supported in Tableau Desktop may not yet be supported in

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep. To view the available functions for Tableau Prep, review the function list in

section: Configuration options include:
text: the Calculation editor.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Calculate level of detail

section: Configuration options include:
text: When you need to calculate data at multiple levels of granularity in the same table, you can write

section: Configuration options include:
text: a level of Detail (LOD) expression to do this. For example, if you wanted to find the total sales for

section: Configuration options include:
text: each region, you could write a calculation like {FIXED [Region] : SUM([Sales])}.

section: Configuration options include:
text: Tableau Prep supports the FIXED level of detail expression and uses the syntax {FIXED

section: Configuration options include:
text: [Field1],[Field2] : Aggregation([Field)}.

section: Configuration options include:
text: LOD expressions have two parts to the equation that are separated by a colon.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l FIXED [Field] (required): This is the field or fields that you want to calculate the values

section: Configuration options include:
text: for. For example if you wanted to find the total sales for customer and region, you would

section: Configuration options include:
text: enter FIXED [Customer ID], [Region]:. If you don't select any fields, this is the

section: Configuration options include:
text: equivalent to performing the aggregation defined on the right side of the colon and

section: Configuration options include:
text: repeating that value for every row.

section: Configuration options include:
text: l Aggregation ([Field]) (required): Select what you want to calculate and what level of

section: Configuration options include:
text: aggregation you want. For example if you want to find the total sales, then enter SUM

section: Configuration options include:
text: ([Sales].

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: l INCLUDE and EXCLUDE LOD expressions aren't supported.

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: l Aggregation calculations are only supported inside an LOD expression. For example,

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: SUM([Sales]) would not be valid, but {FIXED [Region] : SUM([Sales])} is

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: valid.

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: l Nesting expressions inside an LOD expression isn't supported. For example, { FIXED

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: [Region] : AVG( [Sales] ) / SUM( [Profit] )} isn't supported.

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: l Combining an LOD expression with another expression isn't supported. For example

section: When using this feature in Tableau Prep, the following requirements apply:
text: [Sales]/{ FIXED [Country / Region]:SUM([Sales])} isn't supported.

section: syntax:
text: {PARTITION [field]: {ORDERBY [field]: RANK() }}

section: syntax:
text: l PARTITION (optional): Designate the rows you want to perform the calculation on. You

section: syntax:
text: can specify more than one field, but if you want to use the entire table, omit this part of the

section: syntax:

section: syntax:

section: syntax:

section: syntax:
text: l ORDERBY (required): Specify one or more fields that you want to use to generate the

section: syntax:
text: sequence for the rank.

section: syntax:
text: l Rank () (required): Specify the rank type or ROW_NUMBER () you want to calculate.

section: syntax:
text: Tableau Prep supports RANK(), RANK_DENSE(), RANK_MODIFIED(), RANK_

section: syntax:
text: PERCENTILE(), and ROW_NUMBER() functions.

section: syntax:
text: l DESC or ASC (optional): Represents descending (DESC) or ascending (ASC) order. By

section: syntax:
text: default, rank is sorted in descending order, so you don't need to specify this in the

section: syntax:
text: expression. If you want to change the sort order, add ASC to the expression.

section: syntax:
text: You can also include both options in the function. For example if you wanted to rank a

section: syntax:
text: selection of rows, but wanted to sort the rows in ascending order, then apply the rank in

section: descending order, you would include these two options in the expression. For example:
text: {PARTITION [Country], [State]: {ORDERBY [Sales] ASC,[Customer

section: descending order, you would include these two options in the expression. For example:
text: Name] DESC: RANK() }}

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: Multi-row calculations let you compute values between multiple rows of data in your flow. While

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: similar to table calculations in Tableau, multi-row calculations apply to your entire data set when

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: you run your flow. You can also build on the results using other types of calculations.

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: Note: When creating a calculated field, don't use the reserved name "Number of Records".

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: Using this reserved name will result in a permission-related error.

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: In Tableau, table calculations only apply to values in your visualization. While you can build on

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: the result, you must use another table calculation to do so. For more information about using

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: Performing table calculations during data preparation can provide greater flexibility when

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: analyzing data in Tableau. You can easily reuse the calculation when building your view and the

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: underlying calculation isn't impacted by filtering. Workbook load times for large data sets can be

section: Tile calculations include the following elements:
text: faster as the table calculation isn't recalculated after the query runs.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:

text: l Fill Down calculations: Computes and fills in missing data from the rows above.

text: l Running calculations: Computes the sum or average of values in a column.

text: Create Calculated Fields with Tableau Agent

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Supported in Tableau Prep Web Authoring version 2024.2 and later.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Note: Einstein Copilot has been renamed Tableau Agent, as the platform expands to

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: accommodate more AI agent functionality. Starting in October 2024, you'll see updates to

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: page sections, field names, and other UI text throughout Tableau Prep, Tableau Catalog,

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: and Tableau Cloud Web Authoring. Help content and Trailhead modules are also being

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: updated to reflect these changes.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Creating calculated fields is now easier than ever with Tableau Agent. Just describe a

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: calculation, and Tableau Agent will create the formula, allowing you to add powerful calculated

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: fields to your Prep flows with a single click. Previously, creating formulas for calculated fields

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: required an understanding of objects and fields, available functions, and various limitations

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: based on data types, formula types, and more.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Tableau Agent greatly simplifies the task of creating custom functions. Now both technical and

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: non-technical users can easily create calculations using plain language. With the ability to quickly

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: and efficiently create both row-level and summary formula fields from natural language

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: descriptions, you can perform data preparation, making it easier and faster to combine, shape,

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: and clean data for analysis.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Starting in version 2025.1, Tableau Agent supports English (en_US) and a subset of other

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: languages. If your Cloud site is set to a language not supported, Tableau Agent responses will be

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: in English (en_US). For more information about supported languages, see AI in Tableau

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: supported languages and locales.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Note: You must have Tableau+ and a connection to a Salesforce org with Einstein

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: generative AI set up to use Tableau Agent in Tableau Prep. For more information, see

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Turn On AI in Tableau for Your Site. If you don't have Tableau+ but want to try Tableau

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Agent, you can sign up for a Tableau Cloud free trial which now includes Tableau Agent

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: features.

text: Tips for getting the best results

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: l Stick to basic instructions that result in calculation syntax.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: l Use a verb-noun structure.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: l Preferred: Write a calculation to extract the characters from the field…

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: l Not preferred: For extracting characters, how can I change the way…

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: l Use proper grammar and spelling.

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: Tableau Agent is still learning how to build accurate Tableau Prep calculations. Some

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: calculations created by Tableau Agent won’t be written the way you expected. When this

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: happens, your feedback about what’s wrong with the calculation helps Tableau Agent continue

section: Tableau Prep currently supports the following multi-row calculations:
text: to improve and build increasingly accurate calculations.

text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: Sometimes analyzing data from a spreadsheet or crosstab format can be difficult in Tableau.

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: Tableau prefers data to be "tall" instead of "wide", which means that you often have to pivot your

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: data from columns to rows so that Tableau can evaluate it properly.

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: However you may also have scenarios where your data tables are tall and narrow and are too

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: normalized to properly analyze. For example a sales department that tracks advertising spend in

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: two columns, one called Advertising that contains rows for radio, television and print and one

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: column for total spent. In this type of scenario, to analyze this data as separate measures you

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: would need to pivot that row data to columns.

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: But what about pivoting larger data sets or data that changes frequently over time? You can use

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: a wildcard pattern match to search for fields that match the pattern and automatically pivot the

section: Example Calculation 2:
text: data.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Use Python scripts in your flow

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Disclaimer: This topic includes information about a third-party product. Please note that

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: while we make every effort to keep references to third-party content accurate, the

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: information we provide here might change without notice as python changes. For the most

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: up-to-date information, please consult the python documentation and support.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Python is a widely used high-level programming language for general-purpose programming. By

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: sending Python commands to an external service through Tableau Prep Builder, you can easily

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: extend your data preparation options by performing actions like adding row numbers, ranking

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: fields, filling down fields and performing other cleaning operations that you might otherwise do

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: using calculated fields.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: To include Python scripts in your flow, you need to configure a connection between Tableau and

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: a TabPy server. Then you can use Python scripts to apply supported functions to data from your

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: flow using a pandas dataframe. When you add a script step to your flow and specify the

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: configuration details, file, and function that you want to use, data is securely passed to the TabPy

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Tableau Software 349

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: server, the expressions in the script are applied, and the results are returned as a table that you

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: can clean or output as needed.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: You can run flows that include script steps in Tableau Server as long as you have configured a

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: connection to your TabPy server. Running flows with script steps in Tableau Cloud, isn't

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: currently supported. To configure Tableau Server, see Configure the Tableau Python

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: (TabPy) server for Tableau Server below.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: For information about how to configure sites on Tableau Server with analytics extensions for

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: workbooks, see Configure Connections with Analytics Extensions.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Prerequisites

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: To include Python scripts in your flow, complete the following setup. Creating or running flows

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: with script steps in Tableau Cloud isn't currently supported.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: 1. Download and install Python. Download and install the most current version of Python for

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: Linux, Mac or Windows.

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: 2. Download and install the Tableau Python server (TabPy). Follow the installation and

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: configuration instructions for installing TabPy. Tableau Prep Builder uses TabPy to pass

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: data from your flow through TabPy as the input, applies your script, then returns the

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: results back to the flow. 3. Install Pandas. Run pip3 install pandas. You must use a pandas data frame in

section: Start your Rserve server then complete the following steps:
text: your scripts to integrate with Tableau Prep Builder.

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: Aggregate and group values

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: Sometimes you’ll need to adjust the granularity of some data, either to reduce the amount of

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: data produced from the flow, or to align data with other data you might want to join or union

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: together. For example, you might want to aggregate sales data by customer before joining a

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: sales table with a customer table.

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: If you need to adjust the granularity of your data, use the Aggregate option to create a step to

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: group and aggregate data. Whether data is aggregated or grouped depends on the data type

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: (string, number, or date).

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: 1. In the Flow pane, click the plus icon, and select Aggregate. A new aggregation step

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: displays in the Flow pane and the Profile pane updates to show the aggregate and group

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: profile.

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: 2. Drag fields from the left pane to the Grouped Fields pane (the fields that make the row)

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: or to the Aggregated Fields pane (the data that will be aggregated and presented at the

section: Start your TabPy server then complete the following steps:
text: level of the grouped fields).

section: You can also:
text: Join your data

section: You can also:
text: The data that you want to analyze is often made up of a collection of tables that are related by

section: You can also:
text: specific fields. Joining is a method for combining the related data on those common fields. The

section: You can also:
text: result of combining data using a join is a table that’s typically extended horizontally by adding

section: You can also:
text: fields of data.

section: You can also:
text: Joining is an operation you can do anywhere in the flow. Joining early in a flow can help you

section: You can also:
text: understand your data sets and expose areas that need attention right away.

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: Left For each row, includes all values from the left table and corresponding

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: matches from the right table. When a value in the left table doesn't have a cor-

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: Right For each row, includes all values from the right table and corresponding

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: matches from the left table. When a value in the right table doesn't have a cor-

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: responding match in the left table, you see a null value in the join results.

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: leftOnly For each row, includes only values from the left table that don't match any val-

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: ues from the right table. Field values from the right table show as null values in

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: the join results.

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: rightOnly For each row, includes only values from the right table that don't match any val-

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: the join results.

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: notInner For each row, includes all of the values from the right and the left table that

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:
text: Full For each row, includes all values from both tables. When a value from either

section: Tableau Prep supports the following join types:

section: the values as not matching and exclude them from the join:

section: the values as not matching and exclude them from the join:
text: another table. Make sure the tables you union have the same number of fields, the same field

section: the values as not matching and exclude them from the join:

section: the values as not matching and exclude them from the join:

section: To apply Einstein Discovery predictions to your flow, you will need:
text: 1. Open Tableau Prep and connect to a data source.

section: To apply Einstein Discovery predictions to your flow, you will need:
text: 2. Apply any cleaning operations as needed.

section: To apply Einstein Discovery predictions to your flow, you will need:
text: 3. Click the plus icon and select Prediction from the Add menu.

section: To apply Einstein Discovery predictions to your flow, you will need:
text: 4. In the Prediction pane on the Settings tab, do one of the following, depending on your

section: version:
text: l Version 2021.2 and later: In the Connection drop-down, connect to your

section: version:
text: Salesforce server or select your Salesforce server from the list if you already have

section: version:
text: a connection established.

section: version:
text: 376 Tableau Software

section: version:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: version:
text: l Version 2021.1.4 and earlier: Click Connect to Einstein Discovery.

section: version:
text: When connecting for the first time, a web page opens, asking you to sign in to your

section: version:
text: Salesforce account using your Salesforce credentials. After you sign in, a web page opens

section: version:
text: asking if you want to let Tableau access your Salesforce data. Click Allow to continue, and

section: version:
text: then close the resulting tab in your browser.

section: version:
text: 5. Click Select Prediction Definition. This opens the list of deployed models that you have

section: version:
text: access to. The models are built and deployed in Salesforce using Einstein Discovery. For

section: version:
text: more information about predictive models see, About Models in Salesforce help.

section: version:
text: Tableau Software 377

section: version:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: version:
text: 6. In the Prediction Definitions dialog, select the prediction definition that maps to your

section: version:
text: data set. To generate predicted outcomes using your flow data, all fields in the model

section: version:
text: must map to a corresponding flow field.

section: version:
text: 7. In the Options section, select up to 3 top predictors and improvements to include in your

section: version:
text: flow data. This is supplemental data you can add to your flow.

section: version:
text: 378 Tableau Software

section: version:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: version:
text: l Top predictors indicate which factors contributed the most to the predicted outcome.

section: version:
text: l Top improvements suggest actions to take to improve the predicted outcome.

section: version:
text: 8. In the Map Fields section, map your flow fields to your model fields.

section: version:
text: l All model fields must be mapped to a corresponding flow field.

section: version:
text: l Field names that match exactly are automatically mapped.

section: version:
text: l You can't map the same flow field to multiple model fields.

section: version:
text: l Model and flow field data types must match.

section: version:
text: If your flow field is assigned to a different data type, you'll need to change it to match

section: version:
text: the data type assigned to the model field.

section: version:
text: To change the data type, in the Map Fields section, simply click the data type for

section: version:
text: the flow field, then select the new data type in the menu. You can then change the

section: version:
text: data type back in a subsequent cleaning step.

section: version:
text: For more information about changing data types, see Review the data types

section: version:
text: assigned to your data on page 163.

section: version:

section: version:

section: version:
text: 9. To apply your settings and run the model against your data, click Apply. The prediction

section: version:
text: results show in the profile pane and data grid.

section: version:
text: If you change any settings, you can click Apply again to re-run the model with your

section: version:
text: changes. If you leave the Prediction step before clicking Apply, the model won't run and

section: version:
text: your changes will be lost.

section: version:
text: Reviewing your results

section: version:
text: After you apply the predictive model to your flow data you can generate your flow output and use

section: version:
text: the new data source to analyze the predicted outcomes at the row level in Tableau. To

section: version:
text: understand the results of the prediction model, let's look at an example.

section: version:
text: In this topic, we applied the Employee Retention Prediction model to our employee data in

section: version:
text: Tableau Prep to get a probability score that an employee will stay with the company.

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: In Tableau Prep Builder, you can manually save your flow to back up your work before performing

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: any additional operations. Your flow is saved in the Tableau Prep flow (.tfl) file format.

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: You can also package your local files (Excel, Text Files, and Tableau extracts) with your flow to

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: share with others, just like packaging a workbook for sharing in Tableau Desktop. Only local files

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: can be packaged with a flow. Data from database connections, for example, aren't included.

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: In web authoring, local files are automatically packaged with our flow. Direct file connections

section: Let's look at what these results tell us for Employee 2:
text: aren't yet supported.

text: Automatically save your flows on the web

section: one of the following:
text: If you create or edit flows on the web, when you make a change to the flow (connect to a data

section: one of the following:
text: source, add a step, and so on) your work is automatically saved every few seconds as a draft so

section: one of the following:
text: you won't lose your work.

section: one of the following:
text: You can only save flows to the server you’re currently signed into. You can't create a draft flow

section: one of the following:
text: on one server and try to save or publish it to another server. If you want to publish the flow to a

section: one of the following:
text: different project on the server, use the File > Publish As menu option, then select your project

section: one of the following:
text: from the dialog.

section: one of the following:
text: Draft flows can only be seen by you until you publish them and make them available to anyone

section: one of the following:
text: who has permissions to access the project on your server. Flows in a draft status are tagged

section: one of the following:
text: with a Draft badge so you can easily find your flows that are in progress. If the flow has never

section: one of the following:
text: been published, a Never Published badge is shown next to the Draft badge.

section: one of the following:

section: one of the following:

section: one of the following:
text: Actions menu and select Revision History.

section: one of the following:

section: one of the following:
text: REST API method "Update Site" and set the flowAutoSaveEnabled attribute to false.

section: one of the following:

section: one of the following:
text: Automatic file recovery

section: one of the following:
text: By default, Tableau Prep Builder automatically saves a draft of any open flows if the application

section: one of the following:
text: freezes or crashes. Draft flows are saved in your Recovered Flows folder in your My Tableau

section: one of the following:
text: Prep repository. The next time you open the application, a dialog is shown with a list of the

section: one of the following:
text: recovered flows to select from. You can open a recovered flow and continue where you left off, or

section: one of the following:
text: delete the recovered flow file if you don't need it.

section: one of the following:
text: Note: If you have recovered flows in your Recovered Flows folder, this dialog shows

section: one of the following:
text: every time you open the application until that folder is empty.

section: one of the following:

section: one of the following:

section: When you save your flow output to an external database, Tableau Prep does the following:

section: When you save your flow output to an external database, Tableau Prep does the following:
text: area for Snowflake) into the destination table. 4. Runs any SQL commands that you want to run after writing the data to the database.

section: following:
text: l Log in to Salesforce Data Cloud and navigate to Data Cloud Setup.

section: following:

section: following:
text: results.

section: following:
text: 408 Tableau Software

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: l In the Ingestion API page, you'll see the available connectors listed under

section: following:
text: Connector Name.

section: following:
text: Tableau Software 409

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: l To find the corresponding Object Name for the connector you want to use, select a

section: following:
text: connector in the list. In the Connector Details page under the Schema section,

section: following:
text: you will see the corresponding objects listed under Object Name.

section: following:
text: 410 Tableau Software

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: 9. The Write Options section indicates that existing rows will be updated if the specified value

section: following:
text: already exists in a table, or a new row will be inserted if the specified value doesn't already

section: following:
text: exist. 10. Click Run Flow to run the flow and write your data to Data Cloud. 11. Validate the data in Data Cloud by viewing the run status in the Data Stream and the

section: following:
text: objects in the Data Explorer.

section: following:
text: Considerations

section: following:
text: l You can run one flow at a time. The run must be completed in Data Cloud before another

section: following:
text: Save output can be run.

section: following:
text: l Wait times for saving a flow to Data Cloud can take some time to complete. Check the

section: following:
text: status in Data Cloud.

section: following:
text: l The data is saved to Data Cloud using the Upsert function. If a record in a file matches an

section: following:
text: existing record, the existing record is updated with the values in your data. If no match is

section: following:
text: found, the record is created as a new entity.

section: following:
text: l For Prep Conductor, if you schedule the same flow to run automatically, the data won’t be

section: following:
text: updated. This is because only Upsert is supported.

section: following:
text: l You can’t abort the job during the save to Data Cloud process.

section: following:
text: l There’s no validation of fields that are saved to Data Cloud. Validate the data in Data

section: following:
text: Cloud.

section: following:
text: Tableau Software 411

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: Data Cloud setup prerequisites

section: following:
text: These steps are a prerequisite for saving Tableau Prep flows to Data Cloud. For detailed

section: following:
text: information about Data Cloud concepts and mapping data between Tableau data sources and

section: following:
text: Data Cloud, see About Salesforce Data Cloud.

section: following:
text: Set up an Ingestion API Connector

section: following:
text: Create an Ingestion API data stream from your source objects by uploading a schema file in

section: following:
text: OpenAPI (OAS) format with a .yaml file extension. The schema file describes how data from

section: following:
text: your website is structured. For more information, see the YMAL file example on page 415 and

section: following:
text: Ingestion API.

section: following:
text: 1. Click the Setup gear icon and then Data Cloud Setup. 2. Click Ingestion API. 3. Click New and provide a Connector name. 4. On the details page for the new connector, upload a schema file in OpenAPI (OAS) format

section: following:
text: with a .yaml file extension. The schema file describes how data transferred via the API is

section: following:
text: structured.

section: following:
text: Note: Ingestion API schemas have set requirements. See Schema requirements

section: following:
text: on page 414 before ingestion.

section: following:
text: 5. Click Save on the Preview Schema form.

section: following:
text: Create a data stream

section: following:
text: Data streams are a data source that is brought into Data Cloud. It consists of the connections

section: following:
text: and associated data ingested into Data Cloud.

section: following:
text: 1. Go to App Launcher and select Data Cloud. 2. Click the Data Streams tab. 3. Click New and select Ingestion API, then click Next. 4. Select the ingestion API and objects. 5. Select the Data Space, Category, and Primary Key, then click Next.

section: following:
text: A true Primary Key must be used for Data Cloud. If one doesn’t exist, you need to create a

section: following:
text: Formula Field for the Primary Key.

section: following:
text: 412 Tableau Software

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: For Category, choose between Profile, Engagement or Other. A datetime field must be

section: following:
text: present for objects that are intended for the engagement category. Objects of type profile

section: following:
text: or other don’t impose this same requirement. For more information, see Category and

section: following:
text: Primary Key. 6. Click Deploy.

section: following:
text: You now have a data stream and a data lake object. Your data stream can now be added

section: following:
text: to a data space.

section: following:
text: Add your data stream to a data space

section: following:
text: When you bring in data from any source to the Data Cloud, you associate the Data Lake Objects

section: following:
text: (DLOs) to the relevant data space with or without filters.

section: following:
text: 1. Click the Data Spaces tab.

section: following:
text: 2. Choose the default Data Space or the name of the Data Space that you’re assigned to. 3. Click Add Data. 4. Select the Data Lake Object you created and click Next. 5. (Optional) select filters for the object. 6. Click Save.

section: following:
text: Tableau Software 413

section: following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: following:
text: Map the Data Lake Object to Salesforce objects

section: following:
text: Data mapping relates Data Lake Object fields to Data Model Object (DMO) fields.

section: following:
text: 1. Go to the Data Stream tab and select the Data Stream you created.

section: following:
text: 2. From the Data Mapping section, click Start.

section: following:
text: The field-mapping canvas shows your source DLOs on the left and target DMOs on the

section: following:
text: right. For more information, see Map Data Model Objects.

section: following:
text: Create a Connected App for Data Cloud Ingestion API

section: following:
text: Before you can send data into Data Cloud using Ingestion API, you must configure a Connected

section: following:
text: App. For more details, see Enable OAuth Settings for API Integration and Create a connected

section: following:
text: App for Data Cloud Ingestion API.

section: following:
text: As part of your Connected App set up for Ingestion API, you must select the following OAuth

section: scopes:
text: l Access and manage your Data Cloud Ingestion API data (cdp_ingest_api)

section: scopes:
text: l Manage Data Cloud profile data (cdp_profile_api)

section: scopes:
text: l Perform ANSI SQL queries on Data Cloud data (cdp_query_api)

section: scopes:
text: l Manage user data via APIs (api)

section: scopes:
text: l Perform requests on your behalf at any time (refresh_token, offline_access)

section: scopes:
text: Schema requirements

section: scopes:
text: To create an ingestion API source in Data Cloud, the schema file you upload must meet specific

section: scopes:
text: requirements. See Requirements for Ingestion API Schema.

section: scopes:
text: 414 Tableau Software

section: scopes:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: scopes:
text: l Uploaded schemas have to be in valid OpenAPI format with a .yml or .yaml extension.

section: scopes:
text: OpenAPI version 3.0.x is supported.

section: scopes:
text: l Objects can’t have nested objects.

section: scopes:
text: l Each schema must have at least one object. Each object must have at least one field.

section: scopes:
text: l Objects can’t have more than 1000 fields.

section: scopes:
text: l Objects can’t be longer than 80 characters.

section: scopes:
text: l Object names must contain only a-z, A-Z, 0–9, _, -. No unicode characters.

section: scopes:
text: l Field names must contain only a-z, A-Z, 0–9, _, -. No unicode characters.

section: scopes:
text: l Field names can’t be any of these reserved words: date_id, location_id, dat_account_

section: scopes:
text: currency, dat_exchange_rate, pacing_period, pacing_end_date, row_count, version. Field

section: scopes:
text: names can’t contain the string __.

section: scopes:
text: l Field names can’t exceed 80 characters.

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l For text or boolean type: string

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l For number type: number

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l For date type: string; format: date-time

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l Object names can’t be duplicated; case-insensitive.

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l Objects can’t have duplicate field names; case-insensitive.

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: l DateTime data type fields in your payloads must be in ISO 8601 UTC Zulu with format

section: l Fields meet the following type and format:
text: yyyy-MM-dd’T’HH:mm:ss.SSS’Z'.

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: l Existing field data types can’t be changed.

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: l Upon updating an object, all the existing fields for that object must be present.

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: l Your updated schema file only includes changed objects, so you don’t have to provide a

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: comprehensive list of objects each time.

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: l A datetime field must be present for objects that are intended for the engagement

section: When updating your schema, be aware that:
text: category. Objects of type profile or other don’t impose this same requirement.

text: YMAL file example

section: createddate:
text: 416 Tableau Software

section: createddate:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: createddate:
text: Save flow output data to Amazon S3

section: createddate:
text: Available in Tableau Prep Builder 2024.2 and later and Web Authoring and Tableau Cloud. This

section: createddate:
text: feature is not available in Tableau Server yet.

section: createddate:
text: You can connect to data from any of the connectors that Tableau Prep Builder or the web

section: createddate:
text: supports and save your flow output as a .parquet or .csv file to Amazon S3. The output can be

section: createddate:
text: saved as new data or you can overwrite existing S3 data. To prevent data loss, you can use the

section: createddate:
text: Custom SQL option to make a copy of your table data and run it before saving the flow data to S3.

section: createddate:
text: Saving your flow output and connecting to the S3 connector are independent of each other. You

section: createddate:
text: can’t reuse an existing S3 connection that you used as a Tableau Prep input connection.

section: createddate:
text: The total volume of data and number of objects you can store in Amazon S3 are unlimited.

section: createddate:
text: Individual Amazon S3 objects can range in size from a minimum of 0 bytes to a maximum of 5 TB.

section: createddate:
text: The largest object that can be uploaded in a single PUT is 5 GB. For objects larger than 100 MB,

section: createddate:
text: customers should consider using the multipart upload capability. See Uploading and copying

section: createddate:
text: objects using multipart upload.

section: createddate:
text: Permissions

section: createddate:
text: To write to your Amazon S3 bucket, you need your bucket region, bucket name, access key ID,

section: createddate:
text: and secret access key. To get these keys you will need to create an Identity and Access

section: createddate:
text: Management (IAM) user within AWS. See Managing access keys for IAM users.

section: createddate:
text: Save flow data to Amazon S3

section: createddate:
text: 1. Click the plus icon on a step and select Add Output.

section:
2. From the Save output to drop-down list, select Database and Cloud Storage.
3. From the Table > Connection section, select Amazon S3 (Output Only).
4. In the Amazon S3 (Output Only) form, add the following information:
text: l Access Key ID: The Key ID that you used to sign the requests you send to Amazon
l Secret Access Key: Security credentials (passwords, access keys) used to verify
that you have permission to access the AWS resource.
l Bucket Region: The Amazon S3 bucket location (AWS Region endpoint). For
example: us-east-2.
Tableau Software 417
Tableau Prep Help
l Bucket name: The name of the S3 bucket where you want to write the flow output.
The bucket names of any two AWS accounts in the same region can't be the same.
Note: To find your S3 region and bucket name, login to your AWS S3 account and
navigate to the AWS S3 console.
5. Click Sign In. 6. In the S3 URI field, enter the name of the .csv or .parquet file. By default, the field is
populated with s3://<your_bucket_name>. The file name must include the extension
.csv or .parquet.
You can save the flow output as a new S3 object or overwrite an existing S3 object.
l For a new S3 object, type the name of the .parquet or .csv file. The URI is
shown in the Preview text. For example: s3://<bucket_name><name_
file.csv>.
l To overwrite an existing S3 object, type the name of the .parquet or .csv file or
click Browse to find existing S3 .parquet or .csv files.
Note: The Browse Object window will only show files that have been saved
from previous sign-ins to Amazon S3.
7. For Write Options, a new S3 object is created with the data from your flow. If the data
already exists, any existing data structure or properties defined for the object is deleted
and replaced with new flow data. Any fields that exist in the flow are added to the new S3
object. 8. Click Run Flow to run the flow and write your data to S3.
You can verify the data was saved to S3 by login to your AWS S3 account and navigating
to the AWS S3 console.
Refresh Flow Data Using Incremental Refresh
Note: Starting in version 2020.4.1, you can now create and edit flows in Tableau Server
and Tableau Cloud. The content in this topic applies to all platforms, unless specifically
noted. For more information about authoring flows on the web, see Tableau Prep on the
Web in the Tableau Server help.
418 Tableau Software
Tableau Prep Help
Starting in Tableau Prep Builder version 2020.2.1 and on the web, you can configure your flow
inputs and outputs to refresh incrementally so that only the new rows are retrieved and processed
when the flow runs, saving you time and resources.
For example, if your flow includes transaction data that updates daily, you can set up incremental
refresh to retrieve and process only the new transactions every day, then run a full refresh weekly
or monthly to refresh all of your flow data.
Note: To run incremental refresh on flow inputs that use the Salesforce connector, you
must be using Tableau Prep Builder version 2021.1.2 or later. Incremental refresh is not
currently supported when writing flow outputs to Microsoft Excel or CRM Analytics.

section: criteria:
text: Version Compatibility with Tableau

section: criteria:
text: Prep

section: criteria:
text: If new features or connectors are introduced in a new version of Tableau Prep Builder and you

section: criteria:
text: are working in an older version, compatibility may be an issue if you try to open a flow.

section: criteria:
text: Note: Starting in version 2020.4, you can create and edit flows directly on Tableau Server

section: criteria:
text: and Tableau Cloud. Flows created on the web will always be compatible with the server

section: criteria:
text: version you are using. For more information about authoring flows on the web, see

section: criteria:
text: Tableau Prep on the Web in the Tableau Server and Tableau Cloud help.

section: criteria:
text: Similarly, if you publish flows to Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud to schedule them to run using

section: criteria:
text: Tableau Prep Conductor and your flows include new features or connectors that aren't

section: criteria:
text: supported in your version of Tableau Server or Tableau Cloud, you can run into compatibility

section: criteria:
text: errors that might prevent you from scheduling and running your flows.

section: criteria:
text: Version number format

section: criteria:
text: Starting in Tableau Prep Builder version 2022.3, the release version numbering scheme is now

section: criteria:
text: aligned with Tableau Desktop and Tableau Server. In prior versions, the version numbers for

section: Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep Builder had different formats. For example:
text: The maintenance releases for Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep Builder didn't follow the same

section: Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep Builder had different formats. For example:
text: sequence.

section: one of the following:
text: Tableau Prep Conductor was introduced as part of Data Management in Tableau Server version

section: one of the following:
text: 2019.1. To schedule flows to run on Tableau Server, you must be using Tableau Server version

section: one of the following:
text: 2019.1 or later and Tableau Prep Conductor must be enabled.

section: one of the following:
text: To find your version of Tableau Server, open Tableau Server in your web browser. In the top

section: one of the following:
text: menu bar click the information icon in the top right corner and select About Tableau Server.

section: one of the following:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: one of the following:
text: Compatibility between different versions of

section: one of the following:
text: Tableau Prep Builder

section: one of the following:
text: Generally, a new version of Tableau Prep Builder can open flows created in an older version.

section: one of the following:
text: However, compatibility issues can occur when you try to open a flow between newer and older

section: one of the following:
text: versions of Tableau Prep Builder or even when opening flows in the same version of Tableau

section: one of the following:
text: Prep Builder using different computers.

section: For example:
text: l The flow includes input connectors or features that aren't supported in the version where

section: For example:
text: the flow is opened.

section: For example:
text: l The machine that you use to open the flow doesn't have the required input connectors

section: For example:
text: installed or has a driver version for the connector that isn't compatible. Tableau Prep

section: For example:
text: Builder requires 64-bit drivers to be installed to work with flow input connectors.

section: For example:
text: If compatibility is an issue, when you try to open the flow, the flow may open but contains errors or

section: For example:
text: the flow won't open at all and you receive an error message. In the example below, the flow won't

section: For example:
text: open and an error message displays and lists the incompatible features and options for resolving

section: For example:
text: the issue.

section: For example:
text: Tableau Software 449

text: Fix compatibility issues with Tableau Prep Builder

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: l Upgrade to the latest version of Tableau Prep Builder.

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: Click the update button on the bottom of the Discover pane to download the latest version

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: of the product and follow the instructions to Install Tableau Prep Builder in the Tableau

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: Desktop and Tableau Prep Builder Deployment Guide. If you don't have access to the

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: update button on the Discover pane, instructions about how to download the latest

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: version of the product are included in the Install Tableau Prep Builder topic.

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: l Make sure your computer is compatible with Tableau Prep Builder. For example, make

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: sure that you have the 64-bit drivers installed for the connectors used by the flow. To

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: install drivers, see the Driver Download page.

section: To fix compatibility issues, try one of the following:
text: l Open a copy of the flow that has the incompatible features removed.
