section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Day in the Life Scenarios

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: What does it mean to shape data? How does that impact what visualizations can be built and

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: what analysis can be performed? In the tutorials below, we explore scenarios for analysis and

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: visualization, identify the data limitations holding us back, then see how Tableau Prep can help

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: us shape the data to reach our intended outcome.

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Download the data sets and follow along with these day in the life scenarios using Tableau Prep

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: and Tableau Desktop. Learn how to apply the features and functions in Tableau Prep to get your

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: data ready for analysis in Tableau Desktop.

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Give us your feedback. We are just starting to build this section of the online help. If there

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: are specific scenarios you'd love to see here, please let us know. Use the feedback bar at

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: the top of the page to tell us more.

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: To complete the tasks in these tutorials, you need Tableau Prep and Tableau Desktop installed,

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: and you'll need to download and save the data to your computer.

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: For information about how to install Tableau Prep and Tableau Desktop, see Install Tableau

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Desktop or Tableau Prep Builder from the User Interface in the Tableau Desktop and Tableau

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Prep Deployment guide. Otherwise you can download the Tableau Prep and Tableau Desktop

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: free trials.

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Hospital Bed Use with Tableau Prep

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Reaching capacity in a hospital is problematic but so is an overabundance of resources. It's

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: important to understand hospital beds from the perspective of the bed as a resource. However,

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: the data is often stored from the perspective of a patient. How can we take data that captures

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: when patients are in beds and determine the bed usage?

section: Tableau Bridge client:
text: Note: To complete the tasks in these tutorials, you need Tableau Prep and optionally

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: To install Tableau Prep and Tableau Desktop see the Tableau Desktop and Tableau Prep

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: Deployment guide. Otherwise you can download the Tableau Prep and Tableau Desktop

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: free trials.

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: Tableau Software 487

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: You will also need to download three data files. It is recommended to save them in your

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: My Tableau Prep Repository > Datasources folder.

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: - Beds.xlsx

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: - Hours.xlsx

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: - Patient Beds.xlsx

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: The Data

section: Tableau Desktop installed:
text: For our four beds, A, B, C, and D, we track which patient was in the bed and their start and end

section: time there. The data looks like this:

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: If we bring this data into Tableau Desktop, we can create a Gantt chart to show when patients

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: are in beds.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: 488 Tableau Software

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: This is a useful visual. We can see that there are only small gaps in use for beds A and B, but bed

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: C is very under-used. Bed D's patient has no end time, but we could address that with some

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: calculations. This gives us a visual overview of how the beds are used.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: However, what if we wanted to count the hours when a bed was empty? Or compare open bed

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: time before and after a new policy is put in place? There's no easy way to do that with the data as

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: it's currently structured.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: Desired Data Structure

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: By creating some very basic data sets and combining them in Tableau Prep, we can modify this

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: data set into a form that will allow us to perform deeper analysis and create even more useful

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: visualizations.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: Before we jump into Tableau Prep, let's step back and think about what we need to create to

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: answer the question, "How many hours was each bed empty?"

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: We need to be able to look at each bed for each hour, and know whether or not there was a

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: patient in the bed. Right now, the data is solely when a patient was in the bed; we haven't given

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: Tableau information about the empty hours.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: To create that full matrix of all beds and all hours, we'll create two new data sets. One is simply a

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: list of beds (A, B, C, D) and the other is a list of hours (1, 2, 3, …, 23, 24). By performing a cross

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: join (joining every row in one data set with every row in the other data set) we'll wind up with every

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: possible combination of beds and hours.

section: time there. The data looks like this:
text: The Beds.xlsx data set

section: looks like this:

section: looks like this:
text: And the cross joined results

section: look like this:
text: Next, we'll bring in the Patient Beds information, labeling each bed-hour combination as having

section: look like this:
text: a specific patient or not. We wind up with a data set that has a row for each bed-hour, and if a

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Software 489

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: patient was in the bed, their number and start and end times. Null values indicate the bed was

section: look like this:
text: unoccupied.

section: look like this:
text: With the data in this structure, we can perform analyses like this, which enables us to investigate

section: look like this:
text: unoccupied beds as easily as patient beds.

section: look like this:
text: 490 Tableau Software

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: Restructuring the Data

section: look like this:
text: So how do we get there with Tableau Prep? We'll build out the flow in two parts, first building the

section: look like this:
text: Bed Hours matrix, then combining it with the Patient Beds data. Make sure you've downloaded all

section: look like this:
text: three Excel files (Beds.xlsx, Hours.xlsx, and Patient Beds.xlsx) to follow along.

section: look like this:
text: Bed Hour Matrix

section: look like this:
text: First, we'll connect to the Beds.xlsx file.

section: look like this:
text: 1. Open Tableau Prep. 2. From the start screen, select Connect to Data. 3. On the Connections pane, select Microsoft Excel. Navigate to where you saved Bed-

section: look like this:
text: s.xlsx and select Open. 4. The Beds sheet should automatically be brought out to the Flow pane.

section: look like this:
text: Tip: For more information about connecting to data, see Connect to Data on page 75.

section: look like this:
text: Next, we need to create a field we can use to do the cross join with the Hours data set. We'll add

section: look like this:
text: a calculation that is simply the value 1.

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Software 491

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: 5. In the Flow pane, select Beds and select the suggested Clean Step. 6. With the Clean step we just added, the Profile pane will come up. Select Create Cal-

section: look like this:
text: culated Field in the toolbar. 7. Name the field Cross Join and enter the value 1. 8. The Data grid should update show the current state of the data.

section: look like this:
text: Now we'll repeat the process with the Hours data set.

section: look like this:
text: Expand for directions

section: look like this:
text: 9. On the Connections pane, select the Add connection button to add another data con-

section: look like this:
text: nection. 10. Choose Microsoft Excel and then select the Hours.xlsx file and click Open. 11. In the Flow pane, select Hours and select the suggested Clean Step to add it to the flow. 12. From the toolbar in the Profile pane, create a calculated field named Cross Join and

section: look like this:
text: enter the value 1.

section: look like this:
text: Both data sets now have a shared field, Cross Join, and can be joined.

section: look like this:
text: 13. Join the two cleaning steps by dragging Clean 2 onto Clean 1 and dropping it on the Join

section: look like this:
text: option.

section: look like this:
text: 492 Tableau Software

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: 14. In the Join Profile below, the join configurations should populate automatically.

section: look like this:
text: l Because we named both fields Cross Join, Tableau Prep automatically identifies

section: look like this:
text: them as the shared field and creates the appropriate Applied Join Clauses.

section: look like this:
text: l The default Join Type is inner, which is what we want.

section: look like this:
text: l This join will match all rows from Beds with all rows from Hours, as seen in the Data

section: look like this:
text: grid.

section: look like this:
text: A. Join clause

section: look like this:
text: B. Join type

section: look like this:
text: C. Data grid results

section: look like this:
text: Tip: For more information about joins, see Join your data on page 359.

section: look like this:
text: We no longer need the Cross Join fields, so we can remove them.

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Software 493

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: 15. In the Flow pane, select Join 1, select the plus icon, and select Add Clean Step.

section: look like this:
text: 16. Select the fields Cross Join-1 and Cross Join, and select Remove Fields. 17. Double click on the Clean 3 label and rename that step Bed Hour Matrix.

section: look like this:
text: We now have the Bed Hour Matrix data set that contains all beds and all hours and have finished

section: look like this:
text: the first part of building our data set.

section: look like this:
text: Patient Bed Use

section: look like this:
text: Part two is bringing in the patient bed usage. To start, we'll connect to the data.

section: look like this:
text: 1. On the Connections pane, select the Add connection button to add another data con-

section: look like this:
text: nection. 2. Choose Microsoft Excel and then select the Patient Beds.xlsx file, and select Open. 3. In the Flow pane, select Patient Beds, then select the suggested Clean Step to add it to

section: look like this:
text: the flow.

section: look like this:
text: Because the Bed Hour Matrix file is based on hour but Patient Beds is based on actual time, we

section: look like this:
text: need to pull the hour out of the Patient Beds start and end times. Additionally, for the end time,

section: look like this:
text: we want to ensure that if a patent is still in the bed at the end of the day (midnight, hour 24) we

section: look like this:
text: indicate that the bed is occupied even though there's no end time in the data set. We'll add a

section: look like this:
text: calculated field in this new step.

section: look like this:
text: 4. In the toolbar, click Create Calculated Field. 5. Name the field Start Hour. For the calculation, enter DATEPART('hour',[Start

section: look like this:
text: Time]). 6. This takes the hour of the start time and pulls it out. Therefore, "1/1/18 9:35 AM" becomes

section: look like this:
text: simply "9". 7. Create another calculated field named End Hour. For the calculation, enter IFNULL

section: look like this:
text: (DATEPART('hour',[End Time]), 24).

section: look like this:
text: The DATEPART portion takes the hour of the end time. The IFNULL portion will assign an

section: look like this:
text: end time of 24 (midnight) to any missing end time.

section: look like this:
text: Now we're ready to join patient bed usage to the Bed Hour Matrix. This is a bit more complex

section: look like this:
text: join than we did previously. An inner join would only return values present in both data sets.

section: look like this:
text: Because we want to make sure we keep all the bed-hour slots, regardless of whether or not a

section: look like this:
text: patient was in the bed, we'll need to do a left join. This will result in a lot of nulls, but that's

section: look like this:
text: appropriate.

section: look like this:
text: 494 Tableau Software

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: We also need to match when a bed-hour slot is taken by a patient (or patients). So in addition to

section: look like this:
text: matching the bed the patient is in we also need to consider the time. The Bed Hour Matrix data

section: look like this:
text: set just has an Hour field, and the Patient Beds data set has Start Hour and End Hour. We'll

section: look like this:
text: use some basic logic to determine if a patient should be assigned to a given bed-hour slot: A

section: look like this:
text: patient is considered in a bed if their start hour is less than or equal to (<=) the bed-hour slot AND

section: look like this:
text: their end hour is greater than or equal to (>=) the bed-hour slot.

section: look like this:
text: Therefore, three join clauses are needed to appropriately match these two data sets together.

section: look like this:
text: 9. Join the Clean 3 step with the Bed Hour Matrix step. 10. In the Applied Join Clauses area, the default should be Hour = End Hour. Select the join

section: look like this:
text: clause to change the operator from "=" to "<=".

section: look like this:
text: 11. Select the plus button in the upper right corner of the Applied Join Clauses area to

section: look like this:
text: add another join clause. Set it to be Hour >= Start Hour 12. Add a third join clause for Bed = Hospital Bed. 13. In the Join Type section, select the unshaded area of the graphic next to Bed Hour Mat-

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Software 495

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: rix to change the join type to a Left join.

section: look like this:
text: Note: If you drag the Bed Hour Matrix to Clean 3 instead of the other way around, the

section: look like this:
text: desired results can be obtained by using a right join instead of a left join. The order of

section: look like this:
text: dragging the steps matters for the orientation of the join. The join clauses will also be in

section: look like this:
text: reverse order—be sure to preserve the correct logic of comparing the hours.

section: look like this:
text: Our data is now joined, but we should clean up some artifacts from the join and make sure the

section: look like this:
text: fields are tidy. We no longer need Start Hour and End Hour. Hospital Bed and Bed are also

section: look like this:
text: redundant. Finally, a value of null in the Patient field really means the bed is unoccupied.

section: look like this:
text: 14. In the Flow pane, add a cleaning step so we can tidy up the joined data. 15. Ctrl+click (Command+click on Mac) to multi select the fields End Hour, Start Hour, and

section: look like this:
text: Hospital Bed, then select Remove Fields in the toolbar. 16. On the Patient field profile card, double click the null value and type Unoccupied.

section: look like this:
text: We now have a data structure with a row for every bed-hour; if there was a patient in bed during

section: look like this:
text: that hour, we have the patient information as well. All that remains to do is add an output step

section: look like this:
text: and generate the data set itself.

section: look like this:
text: 496 Tableau Software

section: look like this:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: look like this:
text: 17. In the Flow pane, select Clean 4, select the plus icon, and select Add Output.

section: look like this:
text: 18. In the Output pane, change the Output type to .csv then select Browse. 19. Enter Bed Hour Patient Matrix for the name and choose the desired location before

section: look like this:
text: selecting Accept to save. 20. Select theRun Flow button at the bottom of the pane to generate your output. Select Done

section: look like this:
text: in the status dialog to close the dialog.

section: look like this:
text: Tip: For more information about outputs and running a flow, see Save and Share Your

section: look like this:
text: Work on page 383.

text: Recap and Resources

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: 1. Build a data set for each aspect we want to analyze, in this case, Beds and Hours. 2. Cross join those data sets to create a Bed Hour Matrix data set with every possible com-

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: bination of beds and hours. 3. Join the Bed Hour Matrix with the Patient Bed data, making sure the join keeps all bed-

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: slot hours and the join clauses appropriately match patient bed data with the bed-hour

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: slots.

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: We used the following calculations to create fields we could join on. The second and third pull

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: out the hour information from the original datetime fields.

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: 500 Tableau Software

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: Tableau Prep Help

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l Cross Join = 1

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l This simply assigns the value 1 to every row

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l Start Hour = DATEPART('hour',[Start Time])

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l This takes the hour of the start time and pulls it out. Therefore, "1/1/18 9:35 AM"

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: becomes simply "9".

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l End Hour = IFNULL(DATEPART('hour',[End Time]), 24)

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l We could use DATEPART('hour',[End Time]), as we did for Start Time. This

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: takes the hour of the end time and pulls it out. Therefore, "1/1/18 4:34 PM" becomes

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: simply "4".

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: l But we want to indicate that the patient bed that is still occupied (no end time) is in

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: use, not empty. To do so, we'll assign an end time of 24 (midnight) to any missing

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: end time using the IFNULL function. If the first argument DATEPART('hour',

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: [End Time]) is null, the calculation will return "24" instead.

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: A common need in analytics is to determine the date a second event happens, such as when a

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: customer made a second purchase—thereby becoming a repeat customer—or when a driver

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: gets a second traffic violation. Finding the date of a first event is easy, it's simply the minimum

section: To build this data structure using Tableau Prep, we needed to perform the following actions:
text: date. Finding the second date is trickier.

text: Go Further—Pivoted Data

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: While the data we've been working with is well structured to address questions specifically

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: around first and second infractions, it isn't the standard structure recommended for use with

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: Tableau Desktop. The more our analysis diverges from basic questions around the infraction

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: dates, the more complicated our calculations become to combine the relevant information into

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: useable form.

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: Usually, when data is stored with multiple columns for the same type of data (such as two

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: columns for date, two columns for fine amount, etc.) and unique information is stored in the field

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: name (such as whether it's the first or second infraction), this is an indication the data should be

section: ELSE 0 END)
text: pivoted.

section: ELSE 0 END)

section: ELSE 0 END)

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: Troubleshoot Tableau Prep Builder

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: This article lists problems you might encounter when using Tableau Prep Builder and

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: suggestions for how to resolve them.

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: Running LogShark

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: LogShark is a free open source command line utility that you can use to extract information from

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: Prep log files to troubleshoot and gain insight about errors and usage. Using the LogShark

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: Prep.twbx plugin, you can generate workbooks with an error and flow dashboard to help you

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: analyze and visualize Prep issues.

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: LogShark requires that the Prep log files that you process are compressed (zipped) files. To find

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: the Prep log files, navigate to the My Tableau Prep Repository folder. The location is

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: /Users/<username>/Documents/My Tableau Prep Repository.

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: For information about installing and running LogShark, see Get your Computer Set Up for

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END
text: LogShark.

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END

section: THEN 1 ELSE 2 END

text: ABS(number) Returns the absolute value of the given number.
ABS([Budget Variance])
Returns the absolute value for all the numbers
contained in the Budget Variance field.
ACOS(number) Returns the arc cosine of the given number. The
result is in radians.
ASIN(number) Returns the arc sine of a given number. The res-
ult is in radians.
ATAN(number) Returns the arc tangent of a given number. The
result is in radians.
ATAN2(y number, x number) Returns the arc tangent of two given numbers (x
and y). The result is in radians.

ber.

culation.

ans.
ROUND(number, [decimals]) Rounds numbers to a specified number of digits.
The decimals argument specifies how many
decimal points of precision to include in the final
result. If decimals is omitted, number is rounded
to the nearest integer.
